Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki can't be loaded
Post description: Hi everyone, I am a research assistant for a professor and I run my prof's Moodle, which he uses for one of his classes. Both of us think this application is awesome - it's very versatile and based on feedback from his students, many of his students think the same. We do, however, have a recurring problem with the wiki part of the Moodle. Students are required to add content to an overall course wiki, which helps students collaborate and brainstorm with each other and serves as a good central point for study material for the entire course. This is the second semester that we are using the Moodle for a class, and in both semesters once we reach the end of the semester the wiki fails to load. What I mean by fails to load is that the wiki does not load and it seems like the user session "dies" - once you click on the wiki link the browser will sit there loading forever. You cannot reload the Moodle in the same browser/same computer, you have to go to a different computer and login (either as that same user or a different one) to load the Moodle up again. I've noticed that after about 20 minutes, you can reload the Moodle page from a 'crashed' session, so I believe it has something to do with user sessions. Furthermore, by the end of the semester, the wiki gets pretty damn big - maybe it has something to do with this size? We were thinking of setting up two wikis for next term: one containing information for the first half of the course, and the other for the second half of the course. We are using Moodle 1.7.1 (I think). I'm not at my web server right now so I cannot give more details right this moment, but if anyone is willing to help I will gladly dig up logs and do anything else. I am running the Moodle off of a Power Mac G5 (that's our web server) running Apache , PHP and MySQL . One more thing. I went digging through the My SQL console and I see that the wiki content is all there (and there's a lot of it!). I know I can dump the contents of the wiki SQL tables out - is there a way I can use this to re-create the wiki? I just want the students to have access to the information they contributed, as the final exam is coming up and it would be good study material for them. Thanks a lot to anyone who can offer insight and help, Fil

Post title: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
Post description: Besides view, edit, links, and history, have you think about including a disscusion page? (for example see mediawiki at wikipedia) Actually, every page of my class wiki points to a disscusion page. Nevertheless, this disscusion page is the same to the whole wiki, so you have to identify the theme of disscusion, the page, etc. If a disscusion command is included then every wiki page should have its own disscusion page. Best wishes, Juan Miguel

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki in Moodle 2.0 Development plans .... and call for contributions
Post description: Hi there, this week we have started to develope the Wiki for Moodle 2.0. Which is basically NWiki (same features, look and feel, etc) rewriten from scratch ( so the code will be neat and tiddy ). And we need some help to make this rigth, so we never need "to do another wiki ever". Help Wanted: - code revision: By the end of this week we will have the first functional release, just a wiki skeleton with a dumb parser, but with the full database and basic operations implemented. I beliebe that security issues need to be addressed here before we start building features. - markup and page behaviour - There will be a team working sole on the parsers (ewiki for backward compatibility, HTML(whateever editor) wiki, and Mediawikilike markup, and a new VerySimpleWikiFormat. We will use Unit tests to guide de parser development and be sure the things work as they are suposed to. We need you to send (as reply to this post for instance) wikipages with the page content (wiki format) and how is it suposed to be viewed ( XHTML ). If you want your wikis to render rigth in Wiki 2.0 : here's your chance. Thanks in advance for all your help. Ludo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Query re wiki and groups
Post description: Hi all, some help if you can? We use version 2.0.5 and appear to be experiencing some strange things going on in the wiki with groups.  After reading some of the posts here I can't find an exact replica of the problems we're experiencing but there's certainly some similarities although some date back to last year now. I have a tutor using the wiki with separate groups.  After thinking we'd lost content we noted that the tutor has to add himself to a group which then enables him to view each student groups wiki.  The alternative was for the tutor to create a new page which then enabled him to view each groups wiki contributions. We got through this... As students are now getting familiar with the wiki and developing they have requested to view each others groups in the wiki.  Of course the wiki settings were changed to visible and then the tutor is unable to view any wiki content again even though he is allocated to a group!  So we change the setting back to separate groups but I am trying to clarify if this is how the wiki should work and whether if a student contributed to their group wiki whilst the setting was visible and then the setting was changed back to separate would that content still exist. I am still carrying some testing but would apprecaite any feedback! Thanks Kate

Forum Post: 
Post title: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
Post description: E.g. if you create a wiki named like this: 
```text
wiki "suivi scolaire"
```
 You will get: Bad HTML like: 
```text
 a
 href
=
"view.php?id=3770&page=edit/wiki "
suivi 
scolaire"" 
title
=
"Modifier"
>
.....
```
 What's worse: The wiki entry page will show the first version created, but not the most recent version and you will have to go through history to find the page you just edited. ... just spent 30 minutes on this. Of course may can ask why people want to put quotes in names. It's beyond me but a typical thing that people who trust computers might do ;) PS: This is for the standard ewiki module. Moodle 1.9 + (Build: 20080326)

when i try to write characters that are part of any version between 3.0 and 5.0 into the editor, they will not be displayed. even worse, all text that follows gets cut at the first problematic char.

this even applies to this editor i am using to write my message. take, for example, the chinese character nie4, http://www.unicode.org/cgi-bin/GetUnihanData.pl?codepoint=2414A . it is part of the unicode block "cjk unified ideographs extension b" which was introduced in version 3.1 of the unicode standard.

the character is part of the "founder extended" fonts for chinese, i.e. "mingliu-extb" or "simsun (founder extended)". it can be typed into any document using the normal windows ime (above win2k). it can also be typed (or copied from word) into the moodle editor and - while still in edit mode - is displayed correctly.

however, once the page is saved, all text after this character (including this character) will be cut off.

now, if you switch the editor to html-mode and enter the decimal ncr of that character (in this case it is 𤅊), THIS will be saved and displayed correctly.

what is the reason for it?

i have attached a short chinese line with 8 characters in word format as an example, where the 4th character is the problem.

with kind regards,
matthias arnold

Post title: Wiki Questions
Post description: Hello Please excuse my questions. I did read all the docs available on wikis and still have some questions which I can't seem to find answers to. Let me explain: I've been using Moodle for about 6 weeks now with 3 of my classes. In a very small class of 5 students I've used 2 different wiki's successfully having 2 separate groups of 2 and 1 group of 1. Each student adds the definitions of words I listed in a text document. Each student saves their changes without renaming the file. However when I used this method with my larger class of 27 students I ran into problems and had to discontinue using. In this class I set-up 13 separate groups of 2 and 1 group of 1. Each took a text file of terms and had to split the list so that the 1st member of the group looks up the 1st half of the list and the 2nd group member looks up the last half. Students have been advised not to try to make changes at the same time and thus have been coordinating when to make changes. The 1st two groups to use it this week in the larger class could only see their changes when they went to history. Do I have to instruct them to save the page each time they change it using a name framed with brackets something like [student 1 version 1]? Currently, they only hit the save button after making their changes. My smaller group worked successfully without naming their changes.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Create a Wiki with Groups (Step by Step Instructions)
Post description: When I first started using Moodle years ago the forums were very helpful to me. Now that I consider myself somewhat skilled in some of the aspects of this powerful teaching tool, I like to share my knowledge whenever I can. If anyone is struggling (like I did) on how to create a wiki with groups, I hope this step by step tutorial helps. Create a Wiki with Groups (Subject: American War Battles) Create Groups 1. On the course page select “Groups” under “Administration”. 2. On the groups page click the “Create group” button. 3. Fill in the following info for this group: · Group name: civil · Group description: Civil War Group Project · Enrollment key: civil · Click the “Save changes” button. 4. On the group page, make sure the civil group is selected and click the “Add/remove users” button. 5. Add users to the civil group (move them from the right box to the left box by clicking the “Add” button). When finished, click the “Back to groups” button. 6. Repeat steps 2-5 to create three additional groups (vietnam, world1, world2). Make sure to make the appropriate changes to Group description, and Enrollment key. Note: Enrollment key is optional. 7. Return to course page. Create the Wiki Turn editing on. Click the drop-down menu for “Add an Activity”. Select “Wiki”. On the “Add a Wiki” page fill in the following: Name: American War Battles Summary: American War Battles Group Project Type: Groups Print Wiki name on every page: Yes (optional) HTML mode: HTML only Allow Binary Files: Yes Disable CamelCase linking: Yes Group Mode: Visible Groups Visible: Show Grade Category: Uncategorized Click the “Save and return to course” button. On the course page click on the Wiki link. This is where you need to stop for a moment and get yourself oriented. Most likely you are on the “Groups wiki for civil” page in the “American War Battles Wiki (since this was the first group you created). If so, you are ready to begin created your Civil War page Wiki. If you would prefer to start with another war, simply click the drop-down on the top-right of the page labeled “Other Wikis:” and choose the wiki group you want to start with. On the lower portion of the page you should see a bold header: Edit this page ‘American War Battles’. ( I chose to start with the civil group so I will begin editing for the Civil War). Type the following: [The Battle of Shiloh] [The Battle of Gettysburg] [The Battle of New Orleans] Click the “Save” button On the top-right of the page choose the world1 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War I. On the top-right of the page choose the world2 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War II. On the top-right of the page choose the vietnam group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from the Vietnam War. Now the Wiki is ready for students to work in! Student Access to Wiki Go to course page. Click on the “American War Battles” Wiki. Select your group from the top-right drop-down menu. Click the ? to the right of the battle you want to begin working on. Get to work! Note: Students will only be able to edit within their group. Because the Group Mode was set to “Visible Groups” by the teacher, students will be able to view every groups work but will only be able to edit their own.

Post title: Wiki Comments Order Problem
Post description: Hi there, We are experiencing a problem with the order of comments in the Moodle Wiki tool. I've done extensive searching in the forums here and in the Moodle issue tracker, but haven't been able to find anyone else describing the same problem (my apologies if I overlooked something). We are currently running Moodle 2.2.4 and the Wiki is set up to use Separate Groups. What are we are finding is that comments are not always posted in chronological order. It seems to be triggered by editing a comment, though this does not immediately re-order the comments. The edited comment is generally date-stamped correctly with the updated date and time, and is placed at the bottom of the comments. However, subsequent new comments are often inserted somewhere in the middle of the comment thread. To date, in testing, we have not been able to determine a pattern for the misplacements. All new and edited comments appear to be correctly date-stamped. Has anyone else experienced this problem? Thanks, Trevar

Forum Post: 
Post title: Develop 5 FAQs
Post description: 1)Q. Can an 18-year-old student excuse his/her own absences? A. yes 2)Q. can an 18-year-old student leave the school campus at his/her discretion? A. yes, but only with a valid excuse. 3)Q. Do parents and legal guardians retain their educational rights if the 18-year-old student still lives in their house? Who ultimately makes the final decisons? A. No, Even though the student may still live with the parents or legal guardians and is claimed as a dependent, parents or legal guardians only have access to records, but can no longer make any decisons for the students. 4)Q. If an 18-year-old student needs to be transported to the hospital for further medical treatment and is denying treatment, can that student make the final determination or should his/her parent be contacted? A. Since the student is now considered an adult, he/she has the right to make the decision to refuse treatment. 5)Q. Can parents or legal guardians have access to their child's student records even after the child turns 18 years of age or becomes an emancipated minor? A. As long as the parents or legal guardians claim the child as a dependent on their federal income taxes, they retain the right to access their child's student records.

Post title: Individual mode, teacher/non editing teacher can't edit student pages
Post description: In Moodle 2.5 the non-editing teacher and teacher roles could edit student pages when a wiki was running in Individual mode.  We used a wiki with separate groups, in Individual mode, to allow teachers to write notes about each student.  In Separate groups mode, the teacher had a drop-down menu on the left hand side of the page that displayed their group name, and the list of students within it.  Clicking on the student name took you to a page for that student, that you could then edit. Since our upgrade to 2.7, the teacher and non-editing teacher can view the page, but cannot edit it. I’m assuming that this is a bug that got fixed, but I can’t find a tracker item for it.  For us, it was a feature, and one we’d dearly like to get back! Any suggestions from the Moodle community?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
Post description: I am running a translation class, where the students progressively will (I hope) revise their translations of Vergil's Aeneid (or at least the parts on the AP syllabus). I want them weekly to submit their latest translations including the new lines for the next week, but also any revisions they make to their previous efforts. I want to be able to see any changes they make, and to be able to trace any versions back to their original efforts, in case I suspect plagiarism. I considered using the multiple file option of the assignment task, and allow them to resubmit any number of new files (versions), but it seems that a better option might be to use the wiki and have history to show me the versions. A couple of issues occur to me: Will I get notifications when they change things? And will this be too much, if they edit online? Is it possible to compare arbitrary versions of a page, like on mediawiki, or is it just two sequential versions? Can I take a snapshot on the due date, to be sure that assignments are properly characterized as on-time or late? Is this the best way to do all this?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki Locking When in Edit Mode
Post description: One of things I wish the wiki editor had and would really like to see implemented is for the editor to lock the wiki when someone clicks the Edit link so that it can't be edited by someone else at the same time.  As it stands now (in 1.7) that doesn't happen and so a person may lose a significant amount of work because someone else has edited the wiki and saved their changes before the first person finishes what s/he is doing.  It would also be nice if there was a way to automatically update (or save) the wiki when it is being edited -- just in case a person forgets (as I did) to save changes periodically.  I lost nearly two hours of work because someone else in my group made a smalll change in our wiki.  Teaches me a lesson , but also prompted this "wish list item." Mike Ryan

Post title: Best wiki for Moodle 2.0?
Post description: I have been eargerly awaiting our installation of Moodle 2.0 because I was looking forward to the wiki upgrade - but feel a bit lost.  I am guessing that our administrator installed the default wiki inside of Moodle (which is a derivative of nwiki, right?) Is there a place I can go to read documentation on the wiki.  Back in 1.7 we had installed dfwiki and while there were certainly some usability and stability issues that concerned us, but there were many features I liked - I figured that with Moodle 2.0 the wiki that had been integrated would have been an improved version of the original dfwiki.  It appears to me that the current Moodle wiki (wiki2?) actually now has less functionality than the previous ewiki ... (i.e. can not support attachments).  It also does not seem to include the one feature that I know our users (students and faculty) really want - the ability to subscribe to a page - which dfwiki had.  Where can I go to read up on differences between wiki2 and ou wiki?  And is there a current roadmap for enhancements of wiki2?  I am still a bit confused about where Moodle is heading with regards to wikis (which I think are fundamental tools if you are trying to teach in a social constructive environment.) Many of our faculty go to external appliations (like pbworks) for their wikis now - we would prefer if they kept their learning activities inside our LMS as much as possible so our users have a more consistent experience.

Forum Post: 
Post title: searching ONLY current wiki version
Post description: consider this scenario in wiki search: the search feature in wiki module searches in all versions of the wiki , but, the search result displays only a link to the latest wiki version (current wiki) only , after the search process, when the user clicks on the result link (wiki link) it would display the current version only and the user may get confused because the current version may not contain the word he was searching for, but when the user navigates to history tab, and goes through old versions of the wiki, he will find the word he was searching for in one (or maybe more) old versions of the wiki (and of course the word will not be highlited for this case so the user would search for it manually). so for this scenario, the result must display links for old versions of the wiki if these versions contain the search word. so I think the search wiki feature is unreasonable if this scenario happens (and it really happened with me), is there a way to search for words ONLY in the current version of wiki and then display the link for this wiki? should I change something in this line of code: if (! isset ( $_REQUEST [ "content" ]) && ( $dquery [ "version" ] = @ $_REQUEST [ "version" ])) { $dquery [ "forced_version" ] = $dquery [ "version" ]; } this line is on mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php file .. thank you so much in advance. P.S. moodle version 1.9.9

Post description: Hi all, I have a great opportunity to use a wiki on a project I'm working on here at Southampton Uni.  Groups of students (100+ in total) need to post their individually collected data and collate it together. TIA Richard

Forum Post: 
Post title: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
Post description: In a point in time Skodak decided not not support separate student wikis... and all the UPC team exclaimed "Yay!" and we had a beer to celebrate it. Separate student wikis create weird dilemmas to deal with, because students enroll and unenroll. And yet, pedagogically, there is no point to have a non collaborative wiki going on. So we don't support it... Yay! But... there are separate student wikis out there in Moodle 1.x wikis and even on nwiki setups. So... We cannot throw away that content or somebody will be mad at me. The proposed solution : - we create a group with the teacher(s) and the student owner of the wiki, and place the content there.

Post title: Wiki as a resource
Post description: We are experiencing difficulties with the reuse of wikis by teachers... Some of our teachers use the wiki module as a resource instead of an activity. I mean, they are the only ones to produce information for the wiki in order to deliver it to their students (and sometimes to other teachers). And it is true that creating and editing information in a wiki is much easier than doing it on a set of linked webpages (and using the 1.9 fab html editor ;) ). The problem here is about reusing the wiki. They are not able to import it and they are not able to backup/restore because they do not have permission to create new user records. Post title: importing into nwiki problems with tags
Post description: We have been having a lot of problems figuring out the tags on nwiki. We have recently upgrded from 1.8 to 1.9 and installed nwiki When working with a wiki imported from 1.8 constructed in the html editor the tags caused a lot of problems adding a tag to one page overwrote the other pages. However when working with a nwiki or dfwiki created from scratch no problems. Not sure why but it would have saved a lot of time sorting out how the tagging system works if we realised it earlier! Other points it took a while to figure out It was also not clear that tags work across multiple wikis that there is a difference between the tag block (which "administers" tags) and the wiki-tags block (which links to them). hope this helps someone else.

Forum Post: 
Post title: contribution: PostgreSQL tables for WIKI
Post description: Where can we contribute ? maybe a dumb question, sorry didn't had the time to read all the dev. info. mod/wiki/db/postgres7. sql Written by Pim Koeman, Wittenborg-university, Deventer, The Netherlands the moodle_ prefix can be replaced by any prefix Warning : compiles on postgres 7.4 untested on moodle functionality --// cut here //-- CREATE SEQUENCE moodle_wiki_id_seq INCREMENT 1  START 1; CREATE SEQUENCE moodle_wiki_entries_id_seq INCREMENT 1  START 1; CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki ( id int NOT NULL default nextval('moodle_wiki_id_seq'::text), course int NOT NULL default 0, name varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', summary text NOT NULL, pagename varchar(255) default NULL, wtype varchar(255) NOT NULL default 'group', ewikiprinttitle int NOT NULL default 1, htmlmode int NOT NULL default 0, ewikiacceptbinary int NOT NULL default 0, CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki_entries ( id int NOT NULL default nextval('moodle_wiki_entries_id_seq'::text), wikiid int NOT NULL default 0, course int NOT NULL default 0, groupid int NOT NULL default 0, userid int NOT NULL default 0, pagename varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', timemodified int NOT NULL default 0, PRIMARY KEY  (id) ); CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki_pages ( pagename VARCHAR(160) NOT NULL, version int NOT NULL DEFAULT 0, flags int DEFAULT 0, content TEXT, author VARCHAR(100) DEFAULT 'ewiki', created int DEFAULT 0, lastmodified int DEFAULT 0, refs TEXT, meta TEXT, hits int DEFAULT 0, wiki int NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY (pagename, version, wiki) );

Post title: Severe performance issues after import/export to latest dfWiki
Post description: Hey all, I recently upgraded my dfWIki whose pages were created using a 'pre-export feature' version of dfWiki. Forum Post: 
Post title: Heads up: Wiki 1.x interwiki disabled by default
Post description: Hi, wiki 1.x (the one distributed as part of Moodle 1.x core), has one undocumented feature: interwiki links. And it has been there, anonymously, since the beginning of the module. Recently we "discovered" ( MDL-19460 ) it was causing some annoyances to pages named "Wiki: whatever" and others, causing the module to automatically redirect to other URLs (interwiki ones). As long as the feature is an undocumented one (and unsupported) we have decided to disable it by default. So starting next weekly build (June 17th 2009) those interwiki links won't be working anymore under Moodle 1.x. In any case, as last resort... if somebody was using such feature it's possible to enable it again by defining: $CFG->wiki_allow_interwiki = true;

Forum Post: 
Post title: df wiki and groups
Post description: I know this topic has been initiated in other threads but believe the implementation of groups within df wiki needs be addressed in a thread by itself. 1. It appeared from our testing that setting up a wiki to have separate groups kept everyone except group members out of the wiki (including the teacher). In other moodle assignments an instructor is not limited by enabling grouping - which is why you do not put a teacher in a group! 2. Visible groups enabled all others to see other groups' wikis, but also appeared to give them editing priviledges in another groups' wiki. What are the plans for updating dfwiki group features to enable a teacher to be able to view and edit all wikis and to keep the visible group features supported so that if visible groups are used, students can view (but not edit) another group's wiki. We like the group features that were supported in efurt wiki in moodle and would like to see the same type of support (including individual student wikis as has been mentioned in other forum posts). Again - I love dfwiki but the support of groups at this point does not seem to be fully implemented yet - do you have a timeline on any of this - or is there a new version that has been released that addresses some of these issues? We are using dfwiki in our courses now and can not just upload a new version each time it comes out without testing first ....

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ética y Moral
Post description: Ética es la reflexión teórica sobre la moral. La ética es la encargada de discutir y fundamentar reflexivamente ese conjunto de principios o normas que constituyen nuestra moral. Moral es el conjunto de principios, criterios, normas y valores que dirigen nuestro comportamiento. La moral nos hace actuar de una determinada manera y nos permite saber qué debemos hacer en una situación concreta. Es como una especie de brújula que nos orienta, nos dice cuál es el camino a seguir, dirige nuestras acciones en una determinada dirección. La brújula nos indica el camino. En la vida hay que intentar no perder el norte.

Post title: Unexpected interaction between Wiki and groups
Post description: I do realise that this is in the documentation, but I recently discovered that there is a confusing interaction between the "Individual" Wiki and the group set-up on a Moodle page. It's not immediately obvious that, when a Wiki is set up on a course that has groups enabled (either Separate Groups or Visible Groups), the default setting of the Wiki also inherits the groups setting, and once students have created content under the Groups setting, converting to a true individual Wiki makes all of that content unavailable. I know it might not be possible to change this in the system, but I think a clearer description in the documentation of how these settings interact would be helpful.

Post title: Warn your students: beware of reload after edit
Post description: Hi there. The current standard wiki and nwiki versions handle pretty well the concurrence issues. You can't edit a page that other student is editing. BUT. If a user edits a page, saves the changes, and then another user changes the pages... if the firts user goes to the toilet and presses reload when he/she comes back.. then the second edition is lost. Is still in the history but no more in the current page. We need to think about how to deal with this ... I've got some ideas but there are more serious issues to fix before. So warn your students about the reload button!!! Ludo

Post title: Embedded video
Post description: I am using the Wiki module as a way of posting student video tests so only they and I can see those tests. I load the videos into files by grade level, have the students create their Wiki, then use the hyperlink controls to link the videos to the student's Wiki. The problem I am encountering concerns the way videos are linked to student wikis. My videos are created on Mac as a ".mov" file, and Moodle is automatically embedding them in the body of the wiki. This creates some problems loading each wiki and presents problems if I want to place multiple videos on one wiki. It also messes up student formatting of their wiki. I have tried a number of solutions to try to prevent video embedding, but none (at the code level and otherwise) has yet to work. Anybody have any ideas about how I can still used ".mov" files but prevent automatic embedding? Thanks, Kevin

While logged in, if I click on the Attachments tab, the page loads some subset of the total attachments uploaded to this Wiki page, and the top of the resulting page shows what appears to be a pagination link that looks like this: >> [0]. The [0] is a link and if I clik on it, moodle opens the editing interface for a Wiki page. I have seen this same issue raised in another discussion about double quotes management and I thought it would be a good idea to bring it up as a top level issue to make sure it does not get lost. Anyone else with a similar issue (large Wiki page with lots of attachments) and/or workarounds? Thanks, Seb

Forum Post: 
Post title: NWiki for 1.9 Installation issues
Post description: I have just put NWiki on a sandbox 1.9 site, and am having some issues perhaps due to not setting permissions properly prior to the NWiki install. The wiki seems to running fine (lets me create the wiki, create pages, insert images, insert tables, use latex equations,...), but with some problems. In particular, I do not see an index on the left or any of the blocks on the right, nor do I see any way to add these. In my module administration, all things wiki show up with version 2004081200 - (please note errors listed on the front page my site errors shown down on the very bottom of this message). What follows are my steps and results. If anyone sees a problem or can give me some idea how to repair this, please let me know. For my 1.9 LAMP site, as root I downloaded the zip file to my moodle directory, then ran the commands cd /mymoodledirectory unzip -o Nwiki(rest of name).zip to overwrite all previous versions of files. I tried to install but had ownership issues, so after my first attempt, I had to rerun ownership chown -R apache:apache /(my moodle directory)

Post title: Reviewing student entries
Post description: I have a class with 72 students. I have had them create individual wikis on a particular topic. After I have checked their entries, I make them visible for others to review. The problem I am having is in the review. There seems to be no order to how the 72 students are listed in the drop-down menu. Also when they make revisions, I cannot tell who has and hasn't without opening up the wiki to check the history. Is there a way to order the wikis in alphabetical order or in order of last accessed? Thanks Paul Burgmayer Great Valley High School

Forum Post: Post title: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki Post description: I don't know if this should be reported as a bug. Here's what I just discovered after a teacher reported that an embeded (with Multimedia filter) YouTube video was displayed twice in a wiki. If you use the URL as the link text, it will be converted to a hyperlink in the wiki, causing a double link. Like this: ```text

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4uipnBkj-4

``` You must replace the text to fix it:

some texte

You will be provided with a Moodle discussion forum post that includes the post title and post description. Moodle is a free and open-source learning management system (LMS) used by schools, universities, and workplaces to create online courses and manage learning activities. Your task is to classify if the provided discussion forum post is a feature request or not for Moodle. A feature request is a post where the user asks for new functionality, missing functionality (e.g., features available in other apps), new content, or changes/improvements to existing features in future releases. Respond strictly with one of the following labels: FEATURE_REQUEST or NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is a feature request, return FEATURE_REQUEST. If the forum post is not a feature request, return NOT_FEATURE_REQUEST. Use the title of the post and the description of the post to make the assessment. Forum Post: Post title: Wrong words (eg. "++") are matched as CamelCase in spite of "Disable CamelCase Linking" Post description: Hi, Moodlers. I've been in the face of two strange phenomenons under using ewiki on Moodle1.8. Under checking "Disable CamelCase Linking" on ewiki (Moodle1.8, 1.7, ...), Camel case words (eg. UsingMoodle, WikiModule...) does not match as Camel case. On the other hand, unexpected words (eg. a++, a]+[, ...) will match as Camel case. For example: for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i++)    : HTML editor ->  for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i ++ ? )  : View page (ewiki) '++' is linked for new page. I don't expect! Another phenomenons is as following. For example: a[] is an array. a[1]   : HTML editor -> a 1 ? : View page(ewiki) : I want to avoid. a![1]  : HTML editor ->  a[1]  : View page (ewiki) : That's right. a[]   : HTML editor ->  a ? : View page(ewiki) : Oh? a![]   : HTML editor -> a![]   : View page (ewiki) : Oh No! a![ ]  : HTML editor -> a[ ]   : View page(ewiki): huum...O, OK? (How to correct these problems?) The cause of these problems is on following code, in mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "");
    }  else {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
    } EWIKI_CHARS_L/U are used for detecting Camel case words. These constants are used on regular-expression as follows, "wiki_link_regex" => "\007 [!~]?( \#? \[" style="border-right:0px;border-top:0px;vertical-align:middle;border-left:0px;border-bottom:0px;" alt="[^<>\[" src="http://moodle.org/filter/tex/pix.php/25443382e01c0fa744dccb716a12d8bc.gif" /> \n]+\] | \^[-".EWIKI_CHARS_U.EWIKI_CHARS_L."]{3,} | \b([\w]{3,}：)*([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,}\#?[\w\d]* | ([a-z]{2,9}://|mailto：)[^\s \[\] \'\"\)\,<]+ | \w[-_.+\w]+@(\w[-_\w]+[.])+\w{2,}   ) \007x", and $value = preg_replace_callback("/((\w+：)?([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."] +){2,}[\w\d]*)/", "ewiki_link_regex_callback", $value); Most important part is ([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,} . If we set that the "Disable CamelCase Linking" is On, both of EWIKI_CHARS_L and EWIKI_CHARS_U become null (blank?). Therefore, regular expression will become to ([]+[]+){2,} . [*] (eg. [A-Za-z0-9]) is meta symbol that means character class. [*] is not allowed that the inner part of brankets is null. /[]+[]+/ is interpreted as [ ]+[ ] + , then the render of ewiki view page will misinterpret non-Camel case word as Camel case word in spite of Disable CamelCase is On. /[]+[]+/ means that a word matched with the pattern consists of a character ']' or '+' or '['. I propose a modification for this problem. if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "\t");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "\r");
    }  else {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
    } This patch means that CamelCase word consists of 'Carriage return' and 'Tab code', for example : '\r\t', '\r\t\r\r\t'. This experssion is safe since these strings shall not appear in plain text generally. I'm using ewiki in Japanese. After applying this modification I have no trouble under setting 'Disable CamelCase Linking'  On. If you are also in face of this problem, let's try this patch. Label:

Post title: edit opens blank page, international wiki links, and more.
Post description: I have some trouble with wiki module in moodle 1.5.3+ (2005060230) First of all, I have trouble editing existing pages. You can check it on the wiki at http://apuntes.byethost3.com/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=40 Clicking on edit tab of any page, it navigates to: http://apuntes.byethost3.com/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=40&page=edit/PageName which is interpreted as editing a new page called editPageName (i.e., if you aim to edit WikiFormato, you end on a new page called editWikiFormato). Post title: Would a Wiki Work Best? Class and Individual Portfolios
Post description: I am teaching American History II (American History from 1865 until the Present) at a community college.  I have created a theme for the course where students apply and work at a hypothetical historical newspaper.  Each assignment relates directly to this theme, from there application to the newspaper and their vertical progression through the company.  At the end of the semester, the student will have completed a variety of assignments.  I want to create a individual portfolios and a class portfolio to track the development of this course and create a research tool for writing an article on the pedagogy of this course. Would an individual wiki work well for a individual portfolio, where an each assignment gets an individual wiki page? Could I use a group wiki for the entire class where they each post there assignment under the corresponding assignment title?  What I am thinking is that this group wiki would have several main pages, such as Applicant Cover Letter, Obituary Assignment, Internal Memo etc... Then each student would get an individual subpage.  So then there would be say 25 sub pages for each main page.  I want to organize the student work in a way that I can access easily in the future. Any advice would be much appreciated.

Post description: I am not very familiar with the Wiki in Moodle, but one of my users ran into a problem. We are using a fairly stock Moodle 1.9.3 and are not using a special Wiki. We did just recenly upgrade from 1.9.2 to 1.9.3, but I think this happened before the upgrade. It's possible the problem could have been caused by that though. Forum Post: 
Post title: Export - MediaWiki . . . Inport - NWiki
Post description: I have tried and tested NWikis ability to export and import XML files and is seams to work flawlessly. I then got the idea to try and export some pages from a MediaWiki site (WikiBooks) to be precise, and try and import them into NWiki ... Well you can all guess ... it did not work, however, after closer inspection of the MediaWiki XML file I realized that it should be possible to write a parser that would take the MediaWiki XML tags and replace them with NWiki replacements. There are many tags in the NWiki XML file that are LMS dependent, these are what makes NWiki more suited to our educational needs. I am guessing that if there is no corresponding tag in the MediaWiki file then they can be simply inserted with defaults. I am imagining a stand alone parser at the moment but I'm sure that this could be written into the php scripts that read in the XML files and it could be implemented transparently in NWiki. What do the rest of you wiki'ers think? Linds

Post title: sticky login for fictional student
Post description: Hi, I am using Moodle 1.5.2 with a Windows XP Pro client and Internet Explorer and Mozilla Firebird . In order to test a new separate group course, I am logging in under multiple user accounts, my teacher (I am also admin) account plus several fictional student accounts -- made-up names with real yet unique email accounts. I have tried this using both single instances of IE , and multiple instances, each with unique account. One of my wiki resources is set up so the teacher can read/write, students read-only. I find it a great place to create teacher "space" for structured resources. When I log in as a fictional student, I can read wiki entrys. If I attempt to edit them as the fictional student, the edit tab disappears, as expected, I think. When I log out as the fictional student, and log in as me again, the teacher, I cannot edit any wiki entries that were tested by the fictional student -- the student is shown as still logged in for the pages in question. However, I am showed as logged in for other wiki pages untouched by the student. I am using Internet Explorer on the same computer for each session. I closed all instances of IE, and tried again. No luck, the student is still logged in. I repeated the experiment with Mozilla Firebird and was successful -- the student was not logged in. However, when I again repeated the test with IE, the student was still logged in. I restarted my computer, suspecting something "sticky" with IE, but restarting did not solve the problem, the student was still logged in. Does anyone know what is happening here? How do I clear the "sticky" student login? -Ron

Post title: Adding rows to table in wiki - suddenly stopped working
Post description: A group of people at our college use a wiki to collect names and addresses of people who have signed up for part-time courses. I originally created an empty table structure that they could use and each course (a page on the wiki) uses this table structure which they fill in as somebody enrols. From time to time my original template for the table is not big enough so they use the wiki toolbar tool to add new rows. OK so far - I'm guessing there are a whole load of people who already think I am mad. Tables in wikis? Is he asking for trouble? Well as it happens it has been working fine up to a day or two ago. Suddenly one of the people with editing rights discovered that she could no longer add rows. The toolbar icons still exist (in the expanded view) but when she clicked on the icon to add a new row absolutely nothing happened. I couldn't understand that but put it down to something odd with her PC. Today the others in the group are reporting the same problem and now it also affects me. One bright person suggested that everything was OK until the updates and she was referring to automated Windows updates. I thiink she is right because those updates have just been applied to my PC as well. The questions are 'What update could have caused this?' and 'Is there anything I can do about it?' A long shot I know but I hope somebody can help Dave

Forum Post: 
Post title: Simultaneous editing occurs in wiki with overwriting of data as result
Post description: Hi all, We have discovered that the edit protection in the wiki of Moodle 2 is not watertight. Normally, if a (student) user tries to edit a (collaborative) wiki page that is being edited by another user, they would see an error message: " Someone is editing this page right now. Try to edit it in a few minutes. " However, experience has shown that nonetheless it is sometime possible for users to edit a wiki page simultaneously with as a result that the data of the user who saves first is overwritten by the one who saves last. Our tests have so far identified three possible scenarios: An interruption in the Internet connection. If a user, for instance using an unstable wireless connection, suffers a short interruption in his connection, another user can open the editing mode of the same page, provided they click at the right moment. A mix up with open browser windows or tabs If a user leaves the wiki in editing mode in one browser tab then opens another with which he/she also surfs to the wiki and then gets the view mode, another user can open editing mode for the same page even though the first user still has it open. Using the back button If a user edits and saves a wiki page, the pages becomes editable by another user, but the first user can use the back button of his/her browser to reurn to editing mode without encountering the error message. We wonder if anyone else has noticed these and other cases where the edit protection fails? And also if anyone has suggestions for improvements, apart from instructions to students for proper use of the tool. We use Moodle 2.3.2+ Rgrds, Paul.

Forum Post: 
Post title: the "code" tag seems to be not activated
Post description: hello, i'm working with the moodle wiki here on moodle.org and on my installation. paralell i work with some ewiki installations in another context . ewiki supports the "code" tag to be able to integrate code snippets in wiki pages. i noticed that the "code" tag is not interpreted in the moodle wiki. ewiki changes 'code' to 'pre class="markup code"', the moodle wiki lets it unchanged. in the ewiki documentation the difference between 'pre' and 'code' is described as follows: 
```text
#  use the 'pre' ... '/pre' 'tags' for a paragraph of 
preformatted text, that still allowed to use WikiWords and 
simple markup

# with 'code' ... '/code' instead you would really see text as 
you typed it, with square brackets and other escapes not 
garbaging your text
```
 could someone of the developer team please think about activating the 'code' handling as in ewiki? ps. the 'pre' implementation seems to have a bug in the moodle wiki. empty lines in the 'pre' block make the interpreter close the block before reaching the '/pre' tag.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Standard version 2 Wiki doesn't seem to understand groups and groupings
Post description: Hello, Is anyone else having problems with groups and the standard Wiki module in Moodle version 2? I'd like to be able to set up a wiki on a version 2 moodle system in which, "there is one wiki per group, students can change the wiki of their own group only, and they can view the wikis for all groups." When using moodle 1.9 and the standard issue Wiki I often set up a wiki so that small groups of students could collaboratively edit their own group wiki, and view the wikis of other groups (see the yellow cell in the table below). This does not seem to be possible in version 2. Either students are able to edit both their own group's and other groups' wikis, OR they can only edit their own group's wiki and not even see other groups' wikis. The settings for a 1.9 wiki to make this group collaboration possible were (also see yellow cell in the table below): Type: groups Group mode: visible Grouping : Grouping-A (this setting not necessary, but useful in courses with lots of groups) The Wiki settings in version 2 are different. These settings; Wiki mode: Collaborative Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A result in a wiki in which students can edit their own group's wiki AND those of other groups. I was hoping that these settings would emulate the 1.9 version described above (and in the yellow cell below). These settings: Wiki mode: Individual Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A Available for group members only: checked result in a wiki in which students cannot edit a group wiki (to be expected) but can edit their own wiki. They can also see the wikis of other students. The strange thing about these settings is that even with the "Available for group members only" checked, students can see a menu of all students and groups in the course, not just the groups in the relevant grouping. I have tried other combinations of settings, but none get the result I want and used to be able to get in 1.9. i.e. "one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups". This is a bug, surely? For your reference, here are the Wiki types available in 1.9, copied from the help files of a 1.9 system: Wiki types (in 1.9) There are three wiki types: Teacher, Groups, Student. In addition, like any activity, the wiki has the Moodle group modes: "No Groups" "Separate Groups" and "Visible Groups". This leads to the following matrix of nine possibilities: No Groups Separate Groups Visible Groups Teacher There is only one wiki which only the teacher can edit. Students can view the contents. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wiki of their group only. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis for all groups. Groups There is only one wiki. The teacher and all students can view and edit this wiki. There is one wiki per group. Students can view and edit the wiki of their own group only. There is one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups. Student Every student has their own wiki which only they and their teacher can view and edit. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of other students in their group. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of all other students in the course. Unless the group mode has been forced by the course settings, it can be set with the groups icons on the course home page after the wiki has been created. So how can this group wiki feature be emulated in version 2? _______________________ Environment: Moodle 2.0.2+ (Build: 20110413) php 5.3.3 MySQL 5.5.9

Forum Post: 
Post title: OU Wiki to replace current wiki module?
Post description: Well, the wiki module is listed as possibly being replaced by OU Wiki at some point in the future in the Roadmap . The question I would ask here is why was this not done in the transition from v1.9 to v2.0? I know I am being unfair, the amount of excellent work done by a lot of people, (none by me), should not be so casually dismissed, but as a fan of wikis, I am actually appalled that the Moodle wiki is so.. so... dowdy.  It was poor in v1.9, and did not fare any better in v 2.0. I understand there was a substantial debate around a new wiki for v2 but really, the end result is disappointing. I know the perception has always been that MoodleWikis should be course specific, but I would ask why? This may have been desireable a few years ago, but is it still so? For me, Moodle wikis can work at two levels, one is site wide, much the same as Forums and Docs do here, (but with a single login). The other is at a course level. Most educational institutions, and businesses for that matter, could well use a tool with that kind of flexibility. Wikis can be specific, and general, and as a place for all sorts of information. We are now well used to using Wikipedia as a source, but what if a school, for example, had the opportunity to develop a school wide Moodlewiki? What if a class of students had the ability to develop a single wiki for an ancient History class, and their teacher could use that as a fully annotated and referenced demonstration of student learning. Better still, could the teacher then not allow continued development of that wiki at a site level?  Over time, it could become an incredibly valuable resource for a school. Is this not what wikis should be? Rather than OU Wiki, why not use MediaWiki as Moodle Docs does? Why not fully integrate MediaWiki as a part of Moodle. Any comments or suggestions are most welcome.

Post title: ouwiki new release
Post description: (For those who are not familiar with it, the OU wiki is an alternative wiki for Moodle 1.9. It does not replace the standard wiki but is an additional option. It works with the HTML editor instead of wiki markup and is designed to be user-friendly and simple.) I have done an updated release of the OU wiki today. Read information and get it here Not many new features but it does include bugfixes, including the one Glenys posted about in this forum! If you had problems trying to install an older version, please give this one a go. For those wondering what's happening in future, there are no major changes on the horizon. We are planning to add a couple more administrative features - including the ability to revert to a previous version without having to copy/paste it - in the autumn. Also just a note - I am posting this to the wiki forum because it seemed most appropriate, but I don't actually read the wiki forum (obviously, we have our own wiki, so most of it is not relevant). I'll try to remember to keep an eye on this post for the next few days. However, if you need to report a bug, please contact me directly by email/Moodle private message. --sam

Forum Post: 
Post title: Image links failing
Post description: There are various threads about problems uploading images but I can find nothing recent on how to solve problems with image links failing. I had a student inserting an image (that resided on the web) with an address that ended Laughing_buddha_statue_Buddha_gift_m.jpg The image showed up correctly in the editor but only the alternate text showed up in the preview. I tried shortening the name and then it showed up correctly. However, when I experimented to find out the length at which it failed I found I could add letters and numbers until it was way past its original length. Further experimenting suggested length was not the issue but it was to do with the use of upper-case. In particular, if the name began with an upper-case letter it could not move away from upper-case and then back again; if the letter began with lower-case there was no such restriction. So, these are OK... ABcde.jpg ABCDE.jpg abcde.jpg

Post title: Wiki login misbehaving
Post description: I am experiencing problems when users attempt to login to edit a wiki page.  The scenario is as follows: Users visit the wiki page with guest login access. The page instructs them to use login link in footer to edit page. They login and are returned to the page, but login status is still set to guest and the wiki page doesn't display edit tab. They navigate to other pages of the wiki or anywhere on the site and login status shows that they are logged in. They navigate to the page they want to edit through the wiki site map and login status shows they are logged in. This doesn't occur on the users first visit to the page but on all subsequent visits to the site. Refresh (F5) of the page does not change login status In addition, the opposite effect occurs if the user logs out and revisits the page without closing the browser: User visits the page logged in Logs out Navigates to the page with guest login access When the page is displayed, user login status is logged in to their account User had edit tabs for the page Navigating to the page through the wiki sitemap results in guest login status & no edit tabs A sample wiki page that is having this problem is http://www.wels.net/university/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=469 or http://www.wels.net/university/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=469&page=group (link from sitemap) I have observed this behavior using both IE & Firefox browsers. Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki can't be loaded
Post description: Hi everyone, I am a research assistant for a professor and I run my prof's Moodle, which he uses for one of his classes. Both of us think this application is awesome - it's very versatile and based on feedback from his students, many of his students think the same. We do, however, have a recurring problem with the wiki part of the Moodle. Students are required to add content to an overall course wiki, which helps students collaborate and brainstorm with each other and serves as a good central point for study material for the entire course. This is the second semester that we are using the Moodle for a class, and in both semesters once we reach the end of the semester the wiki fails to load. What I mean by fails to load is that the wiki does not load and it seems like the user session "dies" - once you click on the wiki link the browser will sit there loading forever. You cannot reload the Moodle in the same browser/same computer, you have to go to a different computer and login (either as that same user or a different one) to load the Moodle up again. I've noticed that after about 20 minutes, you can reload the Moodle page from a 'crashed' session, so I believe it has something to do with user sessions. Furthermore, by the end of the semester, the wiki gets pretty damn big - maybe it has something to do with this size? We were thinking of setting up two wikis for next term: one containing information for the first half of the course, and the other for the second half of the course. We are using Moodle 1.7.1 (I think). I'm not at my web server right now so I cannot give more details right this moment, but if anyone is willing to help I will gladly dig up logs and do anything else. I am running the Moodle off of a Power Mac G5 (that's our web server) running Apache , PHP and MySQL . One more thing. I went digging through the My SQL console and I see that the wiki content is all there (and there's a lot of it!). I know I can dump the contents of the wiki SQL tables out - is there a way I can use this to re-create the wiki? I just want the students to have access to the information they contributed, as the final exam is coming up and it would be good study material for them. Thanks a lot to anyone who can offer insight and help, Fil

Post title: Besides view, edit, links, and history, why not a disscusion?
Post description: Besides view, edit, links, and history, have you think about including a disscusion page? (for example see mediawiki at wikipedia) Actually, every page of my class wiki points to a disscusion page. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In a wiki you are free to put your comments on the page under construction. (and others are free to read it, change it or throw it away. (It will still survive in the  history of that page.) It is another kind of collaboration: constructing together, very democratic, must be a horor for..
Comment 2: Hi Ger: Think about several long discussions about several points in one page. The problem here is page contents mixing up with content discussions. One discussion page (with its own history) for each wiki page should be very helpful in achieving understable communication purposes. Best wishes, Juan Miguel

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki in Moodle 2.0 Development plans .... and call for contributions
Post description: Hi there, this week we have started to develope the Wiki for Moodle 2.0. Which is basically NWiki (same features, look and feel, etc) rewriten from scratch ( so the code will be neat and tiddy ). And we need some help to make this rigth, so we never need "to do another wiki ever". Help Wanted: - code revision: By the end of this week we will have the first functional release, just a wiki skeleton with a dumb parser, but with the full database and basic operations implemented. I beliebe that security issues need to be addressed here before we start building features. - markup and page behaviour - There will be a team working sole on the parsers (ewiki for backward compatibility, HTML(whateever editor) wiki, and Mediawikilike markup, and a new VerySimpleWikiFormat. We will use Unit tests to guide de parser development and be sure the things work as they are suposed to. We need you to send (as reply to this post for instance) wikipages with the page content (wiki format) and how is it suposed to be viewed ( XHTML ). If you want your wikis to render rigth in Wiki 2.0 : here's your chance. Thanks in advance for all your help. Ludo

Post title: Query re wiki and groups
Post description: Hi all, some help if you can? We use version 2.0.5 and appear to be experiencing some strange things going on in the wiki with groups.  After reading some of the posts here I can't find an exact replica of the problems we're experiencing but there's certainly some similarities although some date back to last year now. I have a tutor using the wiki with separate groups.  After thinking we'd lost content we noted that the tutor has to add himself to a group which then enables him to view each student groups wiki.  The alternative was for the tutor to create a new page which then enabled him to view each groups wiki contributions. We got through this... I am still carrying some testing but would apprecaite any feedback! Thanks Kate

Forum Post: 
Post title: Do not use quotes in ewiki names !
Post description: E.g. if you create a wiki named like this: 
```text
wiki "suivi scolaire"
```
 You will get: Bad HTML like: 
```text
 a
 href
=
"view.php?id=3770&page=edit/wiki "
suivi 
scolaire"" 
title
=
"Modifier"
>
.....
```
 What's worse: The wiki entry page will show the first version created, but not the most recent version and you will have to go through history to find the page you just edited. ... just spent 30 minutes on this. Of course may can ask why people want to put quotes in names. It's beyond me but a typical thing that people who trust computers might do ;) PS: This is for the standard ewiki module. Moodle 1.9 + (Build: 20080326)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thank-you! You just saved me 30 minutes of searching. (Why people want to put quotes in names -- my user created the wiki for her students to discuss a written story. She gave the wiki the name of the story in quotes. It seemed reasonable at the time...)
Comment 2: Hi Daniel,
Comment 3: Hello again, I have just checked that after upgrade I have to rewrite course_id to mdl_wiki_entries in order to show the contents in a wiki with no "strange" characters in its name. I mean: we have a lot of wikis not showing contents after upgrade and it has nothing to do with previous misuse of the editor. Somebody with the same problem? Bye
Comment 4: Auto-answer: wiki_pages table records lost. Stop. No character or id number problem. Stop. More users upgrading 1.9.1 to 1.9.x with same wiki´s loss of information. Stop. Good luck with module

Post title: problem with characters above unicode v.2
Post description: hello,

when i try to write characters that are part of any version between 3.0 and 5.0 into the editor, they will not be displayed. even worse, all text that follows gets cut at the first problematic char.

this even applies to this editor i am using to write my message. take, for example, the chinese character nie4, http://www.unicode.org/cgi-bin/GetUnihanData.pl?codepoint=2414A . it is part of the unicode block "cjk unified ideographs extension b" which was introduced in version 3.1 of the unicode standard.

the character is part of the "founder extended" fonts for chinese, i.e. "mingliu-extb" or "simsun (founder extended)". it can be typed into any document using the normal windows ime (above win2k). it can also be typed (or copied from word) into the moodle editor and - while still in edit mode - is displayed correctly.

however, once the page is saved, all text after this character (including this character) will be cut off.

now, if you switch the editor to html-mode and enter the decimal ncr of that character (in this case it is 𤅊), THIS will be saved and displayed correctly.

what is the reason for it?

i have attached a short chinese line with 8 characters in word format as an example, where the 4th character is the problem.

with kind regards,
matthias arnold

Forum Post: 
Post title: Notifications of new wiki page/activity?
Post description: I think it could be very useful for course members to be notified by email when a student (or anyone) creates a new wiki page.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You can do this with Event Monitoring rules - https://docs.moodle.org/38/en/Event_monitoring
Comment 2: Thanks — I never noticed that option before!
Comment 3: Event monitoring for wiki is really clunky. It is not unusual for users to post to the wiki, then revise several times (sometimes just to improve formatting). Event monitoring sends a separate email every time it is saved — but if I set the threshold higher, someone who makes a single post without revising at all would not hit the threshold. It should provide a way to consolidate multiple edits to the same page by the same user, to eliminate multiple non-significant reports. The report doesn't give the title of the page being edited, only a link. I don't see any way to have all participants notified of changes to wiki.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Blocking certain users in NWiki
Post description: How would I block certain users from being able to access a Wiki? We are using NWiki, and want to put certain info into a wiki that we would like only our managers to view and access... Also, how do you make the search area not case sensitive, as when you perform a search right now you have to have the case correct, for example the word Copper brings different results than when you use a lower case 'c' (copper)? Finally, how do you eliminate the previous versions of a wiki page, I can perform the above search and it will bring up all older versions of the same page? Thanks, Andie
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Create a new role with all the wiki permissions set to 'prohibit; and call it something like 'blocked wiki users'. Then go to 'update this wiki' and click on the tab that allows you to set roles for this module context (locally assigned roles in 1.9) and assign the that role to the users you want to block.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki Questions
Post description: Hello Please excuse my questions. I did read all the docs available on wikis and still have some questions which I can't seem to find answers to. Let me explain: I've been using Moodle for about 6 weeks now with 3 of my classes. In a very small class of 5 students I've used 2 different wiki's successfully having 2 separate groups of 2 and 1 group of 1. Each student adds the definitions of words I listed in a text document. Each student saves their changes without renaming the file. However when I used this method with my larger class of 27 students I ran into problems and had to discontinue using. In this class I set-up 13 separate groups of 2 and 1 group of 1. Each took a text file of terms and had to split the list so that the 1st member of the group looks up the 1st half of the list and the 2nd group member looks up the last half. Students have been advised not to try to make changes at the same time and thus have been coordinating when to make changes. The 1st two groups to use it this week in the larger class could only see their changes when they went to history. Do I have to instruct them to save the page each time they change it using a name framed with brackets something like [student 1 version 1]? Currently, they only hit the save button after making their changes. My smaller group worked successfully without naming their changes.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello Fellow Moodle Users Has anyone had the chance to read my post from Sunday concerning using the standard wiki. I'm hoping for feedback to I can get one group of students back on track next week. thank you. Bruce Frey Dean Technical High School Holyoke, Massachusetts, USA
Comment 2: Hi, Bruce. I read your original post a few times just now, but I'm still a bit confused. Are you using Moodle's group feature to set up your groups or are you assigning groups in your directions? Ie. Johnny and Sarah: Terms 1-12 Jessica and Tony: Terms 13-24 etc.? Backing up a bit, do you have the wiki set as a group wiki, separate groups or as a group wiki, no groups? A group wiki, separate groups would necessitate using Moodle's group feature; a group wiki, no groups would simply allow everyone in the course to edit the wiki. I'm also wondering whether you might be running into an upload limit issue. I've never tried to upload multiple docs to one page. I usually set up a new page for each of my groups. What about trying the option of copying and pasting changes directly into the wiki?
Comment 3: Students in more than one group doesn't work yet. Could be that? http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-11464

TIA Stefaan Plets. Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: I'll take a look into this. It looks like we've lost all of the wiki formatting formats. I will put this in as a bug. mike Comment 2: I take it back. The formats are working. The '==' isn't working because wiki converts them to tags, which Moodle isn't allowing. Martin - Is there a reason to disallow tags? Can we add them to ALLOWED_TAGS or should the wiki use some other tag? mike Comment 3: I think is a very defunct tag, isn't it? Can we use 
 instead?  If we are trying to be forward-looking to XHTML compliance then even that is probably not the best solution.  Is there a better XHTML tag or do we use a style? If we just need a short-term fix feel free to add  to the allowed list as a short-term fix (in stable and dev).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Unable to see images uploaded by students
Post description: I have a very strange problem. If a teacher uploads and inserts an image into wiki page, everything works as it should. The image is visible to all users, no matter which browser they use. A student can also upload /insert an image with no problem. But if she uses Internet Explorer (6, 7 or 8) to view the wiki page, the image (uploaded by her or other student) is not visible. If she uses Firefox , Chrome, Opera the image is visible. The Moodle in question runs on Windows server with IIS . Just as curiosity: on Linux/ Apache server everything works without problem. The CamelCase is disabled Does anyone have any idea?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Well, I guess I found a solution for this problem. In the case of using [internal://image.png] for linking image in Wiki the IIS server sends the reply to browser's image request with status 302 in the header. Since there is no Locaton field in the header IE doesn't display the image as it wants to redirect. Other browsers apparently ignore the status 302 since there is no Location field and the image (which they actually expect from the server) is in the body of the reply. In the same scenario Apache sends the reply with status 200. The setting to change, in order to get things working is enable cgi.nph and set it to 1: from php.ini ; if cgi.nph is enabled it will force cgi to always sent Status: 200 with ; every request. cgi.nph = 1 Additional information: nph stands for non parsing headers. In our particular situation it would allow CGI to print Status: 200 header, which is normally skipped as it is not needed in most situations. Source link. With cgi.nph = 0, no status header is output unless you invoke header(), and then only if your status code isn't 200. With cgi.nph = 1, a status header is always output, defaulting to 200 if header() is not invoked. Source link. Should I create a bug report for this or there is nothing to change in Moodle code?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Create a Wiki with Groups (Step by Step Instructions)
Post description: When I first started using Moodle years ago the forums were very helpful to me. Now that I consider myself somewhat skilled in some of the aspects of this powerful teaching tool, I like to share my knowledge whenever I can. If anyone is struggling (like I did) on how to create a wiki with groups, I hope this step by step tutorial helps. Create a Wiki with Groups (Subject: American War Battles) Create Groups 1. On the course page select “Groups” under “Administration”. 2. On the groups page click the “Create group” button. 3. Fill in the following info for this group: · Group name: civil · Group description: Civil War Group Project · Enrollment key: civil · Click the “Save changes” button. 4. On the group page, make sure the civil group is selected and click the “Add/remove users” button. 5. Add users to the civil group (move them from the right box to the left box by clicking the “Add” button). When finished, click the “Back to groups” button. 6. Repeat steps 2-5 to create three additional groups (vietnam, world1, world2). Make sure to make the appropriate changes to Group description, and Enrollment key. Note: Enrollment key is optional. 7. Return to course page. Create the Wiki Turn editing on. Click the drop-down menu for “Add an Activity”. Select “Wiki”. On the “Add a Wiki” page fill in the following: Name: American War Battles Summary: American War Battles Group Project Type: Groups Print Wiki name on every page: Yes (optional) HTML mode: HTML only Allow Binary Files: Yes Disable CamelCase linking: Yes Group Mode: Visible Groups Visible: Show Grade Category: Uncategorized Click the “Save and return to course” button. On the course page click on the Wiki link. This is where you need to stop for a moment and get yourself oriented. Most likely you are on the “Groups wiki for civil” page in the “American War Battles Wiki (since this was the first group you created). If so, you are ready to begin created your Civil War page Wiki. If you would prefer to start with another war, simply click the drop-down on the top-right of the page labeled “Other Wikis:” and choose the wiki group you want to start with. On the lower portion of the page you should see a bold header: Edit this page ‘American War Battles’. ( I chose to start with the civil group so I will begin editing for the Civil War). Type the following: [The Battle of Shiloh] [The Battle of Gettysburg] [The Battle of New Orleans] Click the “Save” button On the top-right of the page choose the world1 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War I. On the top-right of the page choose the world2 group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from World War II. On the top-right of the page choose the vietnam group from the drop-down menu. Repeat steps 7-8 but replace the battles with battles from the Vietnam War. Now the Wiki is ready for students to work in! Student Access to Wiki Go to course page. Click on the “American War Battles” Wiki. Select your group from the top-right drop-down menu. Click the ? to the right of the battle you want to begin working on. Get to work! Note: Students will only be able to edit within their group. Because the Group Mode was set to “Visible Groups” by the teacher, students will be able to view every groups work but will only be able to edit their own.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki Comments Order Problem
Post description: Hi there, We are experiencing a problem with the order of comments in the Moodle Wiki tool. I've done extensive searching in the forums here and in the Moodle issue tracker, but haven't been able to find anyone else describing the same problem (my apologies if I overlooked something). We are currently running Moodle 2.2.4 and the Wiki is set up to use Separate Groups. What are we are finding is that comments are not always posted in chronological order. It seems to be triggered by editing a comment, though this does not immediately re-order the comments. The edited comment is generally date-stamped correctly with the updated date and time, and is placed at the bottom of the comments. However, subsequent new comments are often inserted somewhere in the middle of the comment thread. To date, in testing, we have not been able to determine a pattern for the misplacements. All new and edited comments appear to be correctly date-stamped. Has anyone else experienced this problem? Thanks, Trevar
Comments associated with the post:

Comment 2: I am getting same problem and i am trying to fix it.
If someone can help me regarding it.
Regards
Jack.

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Isabelle, At a guess this might be much less to do with a conscious decision not to include wiki posts for whatever reason, and much more to do with the forum module (for example in 2.3.4) having a function forum_get_recent_mod_activity(...) , but the wiki having no comparable wiki_get_recent_mod_activity(...) !
