Post description: I have an instructor that is creating a table for his wiki assignment and the students are not being able to see the table when they open up the assignment. In the Summary box, he clicks on the "insert table" icon and setups the table. When a student opens up the activity, all that is visible are the instructions-where is the table?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I cannot replicate this at all. Perhaps you could have them create a new wiki and provide some snaps, step by step, or if you wish you could provide me access and I can look at it.... I initially thought this was because the teacher was a newbe and was putting the table in a student wiki after the wiki was created, which would of course only be seen by the teacher..... but that is not what you are describing....
Comment 2: For some reason my fastcapture screen shot is not letting me paste the shot here, so I will tell you that in the settings the type is "student". IF this is wrong, where can that be changed? I've only been working with Moodle about 4 weeks so everything is very different. Thank you.
Comment 3: It looks like you are the IT Trainer/HelpDesk person in an IT staff of 5. Are you also the admin for your Moodle or would that be Eric Hall? I find that talking through intermediaries is problematic as I rarely get the whole story.... If you are the Moodle Admin and have yourself replicated the issue that is fine, otherwise I suggest you have the user follow my suggestions, to wit: create a new wiki from scratch and take a screenshot at every setting, saving the screen shots as png files, then zip up the files and attach to a post to the forum..... You'll notice that there is an image icon in the editor toolbar in this forumto embed images, but if there are multiple images it is best to avoid the impact to the forum and attach a zip..... There is nothing wrong with setting a wiki to "student", but once you do that you create individual wikis, and if you as teacher try to edit the wiki, you are not editing the student wiki, but your own..... But, since you said that IS NOT what the instructor did (you said the instructor edited the summary, not the actual wiki) that is not an issue. The other alternative would be to have your Moodle admin give someone access to your Moodle to look at what the situation is. I'd be happy to do that for you as would, I am sure, others...... I did note that you are at 1.9.2 and while I am not an advocate of beating oneself to have the latest release, it might not hurt to upgrade.
Comment 4: Marc Thank you for your help-I was able to replicate our teacher's problem but I found a way to make it work for him. Once the assignment is created, he clicks on the assignment from the home page and EDITS the wiki in the bottom half of the page and this is where he puts his table and now the students can click" view and then edit" and it works. Grant Carmichael is our Moodle Adm.-not Eric-and I joined the team mid-August of this year as a trainer/helpdesk. I'm learning a lot of information in a very short,quick time and these forums are very useful. Thanks again.
Comment 5: I think you are mistaken, at least your description of your solution does not square with your recitation of the problem. If the instructor is indeed creating student wikis, then after he has created it he will see a listing of every student when he opens the wiki. If he edits the wiki in this view he changes only the instructors version of the wiki, not the students. On the other side of the coin, the student does not see the material the teacher added to the wiki unless the teacher edits that specific student's wiki. As far as I know there is no way for a teacher to make universal changes to all the wikis, which is one reason it is handy to learn how to set up multipage student wikis.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Creating a wiki infrastructure
Post description: I teach history at a community college and just switched from
Blackboard to Moodle primarily because of the built in wiki
application. Part of the class is a collaborative assignment where
groups of 2 or 3 students will research their own project. They are
each going edit their own page, which everyone can see, but only that
group can edit. I also want to create a central page from which there
are links to all the group pages. My main question is should there just
be one wiki and many pages, or many wikis linked to eachother? I have
already grouped the students, but how do I assign a page or wiki to a
specific group? Thanks, GP
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Gary.  I've done something similar except I kept each group's work private.  I don't think there's a way to assign pages to specific groups, so that's something to keep in mind and pushes you to many wikis, which you can assign to groups.  Here's my recommendation. Let's say you have 3 groups.  You can create a wiki, call it "project".  In the setup page choose "groups" type with "visible groups" mode.  By doing this, you're automatically making as many wikis as you have groups. When you save your setup, the HTML editor will open up so you can compose the main page.  If you look at the top left of the screen, you'll see that you are actually editing the home page for one specific group.  On the top right, there is a drop-down box labeled "choose other wikis" or something like that which allows you to create a main page for each of your groups, one by one.  Cutting and pasting works well if you want the main pages to be the same. Students will see only one link on their main course page - it will just say Project with a wiki icon.  When they click on it, it will open one group's wiki - I would hope the one they can write on, but I'm not sure about that because I've never done visible groups.  They should have a drop-down box that would allow them to navigate among the different wikis. One caution -  you want to make sure that you don't have duplicate page names.  For example, maybe you're thinking about setting up each group with a main page that links to pages called "overview" "outline" and "resources".  You need to individualize the page names to, say, "overview-1" for group 1, "overview-2" for group 2 and so on.  Otherwise, unexpected things happen when you try to navigate to your own  overview page - you could easily end up on some other group's.  Even with separate groups, duplicate page names were a problem for me, and I can only guess it would be worse with visible groups. Good luck with it.  I think wikis are a great collaboration tool.
Comment 2: Thanks Russ, That helps, but I am not there yet. How do I link to other wikis from the central or homepage wiki. I was able to link to other pages within the main wiki, but students cannot edit that. I also can't seem to change page names of other wikis. What I want to end up with is a main wiki page that only I can edit which serves as an index of topics, each linking to another group wiki. Everyone can see everything but only edit their own. Thanks, Gary
Comment 3: Gary, I think you're going to have difficulty setting up the scheme you
have in mind if I understand it correctly.  Every wiki in your
moodle has a link displayed on the main course page.  You could
set up a page (not a wiki per se, but just a topic summary) that names
the various wikis for the different groups and they will link
automatically, but I don't think you can force students to access the
wikis this way because each wiki will still have its own link on the
main page.  The duplication quickly gets confusing, and is
unnecessary because the drop down menu I mentioned allows students to
access all the other groups' wikis anyway.  In other words, the
model I suggested doesn't have a "central" wiki, but just the
individual group wikis which are all of equal rank (none more central
than the others). One other point in case this is not clear already:  When you set
up wikis in groups mode, every group in your class will automatically
have the wiki with the same name.  So you need to give it a
generic name.  For example: suppose your project is about flowers
and you have groups working on petunias, sunflowers, and tulips. 
If you set up a group wiki named Petunia, EVERY group will have a
petunia wiki - even the tulip folks.  I would call the wiki
"flowers" and use the specific flowers as group names.  Then, the
choose wiki drop-down list will be clear because it gives the wiki name
and the group name: Petunias: flowers Tulips:flowers Sunflowers:flowers Not very elegant, but it is clear and I think it gives students the navigation tool you seem to want. Hope this is not too confusing. Russ
Comment 4: Thanks Russ, In the interest of time, I am using just one wiki this semester. There is one central wiki which links to group pages. We are going to use the honor system of only editing your own group page, of course having the history of edits will help to scare any would be sabatoers. I may try to modify the system for next semester, when my school will also upgrade our version of moodle. Gary
Comment 5: Hi, Just getting started with wikis in Moodle. Very familiar with them via wikispaces and Wetpaint. I have a class project where each group of students (4-5) will work on a wiki, but haven't had any luck getting the Separate Groups to work. All students can access and edit all wikis still, even when I move kids individually into the separate groups. I'm missing the part of how the wiki gets assigned to the specific group of students. Suggestions? Thanks, Tom
Comment 6: Let's assume that you created a course with group mode set and then in the course created groups and then populated the groups. Then you created a wiki (erfurtwiki, dfwiki, nwiki?) and set the wiki type to groups (as opposed to student or teacher), and then set the Group mode appropriately (you indicate you set it to "Separate".) At this point if one of the students in Group A logs in they should only have access to the Group A wiki..... if that is not the case, please double check your steps

Post title: Wiki's are only created for one group - HELP!!
Post description: Hi there. Basically, I'm having a problem. I'm trying to create Wiki's for three Year 8 classes enrolled on a Year 8 ICT course; the three classes are enrolled on the course as three seperate groups. Now, whenever I create a Wiki it only ever assigns it to one group and doesn't give me any options that I can see to change this. This has the effect that only that group can access the Wiki's properly and get all the edited pages; the other two groups can open the Wiki's but they get a blank Wiki displayed instead. They can edit this and it saves the changed for themselves only. The Wiki's are set for "Groups" and "Seperate Groups". At the top of each one it says "Groups Wiki for 8AL" (8AL is the one group that everything gets set to, the others are 8CP and 8GH). Please can anyone offer any advice, as I am stumped!? Thanks in advance! - Nathan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Nathan When you have groups set on a wiki you see an additional 'Other wikis' dropdown on the top right of the screen. Similar to using groups in a forum you have to select the group you wish to "type to". Change this to each other group (eg 8CP then 8GH) to "start them off". The initial text you typed in the blank edit screen will probably already be in place for 8AL. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa
Comment 2: I have a similar problem. I am using groups in the course, three sections . I have choosen separate groups for the wiki, but would like to choose students as the type. I read the post above, but when I click the dropdown I see all student wiki's. I know I'm doing something wrong, but what? How does this work?

Post description: Hi, I am trying to find a solution for being able to grade Wiki entries and tie them to Gradebook. From an educational point of view, we are trying to motivate students to create a Wiki (because of the Wiki nature of allowing to build content over time) but also have the capability of grading what each student enters in the Wiki. I have searched a few hours and have not found any information or plugin about this. I'm currently working with the standard Moodle eWiki installation but am open on upgrading to nWiki if that's the case. Would Moodle 2.0 have this functionality? Is it even worth considering building a plugin? I'm hoping someone can point me in the right direction on finding a solution for this. Thanks.

We (dfwikiteam) have designed and developed ( in this case thinking is the tougth part ) a way to grade wikis and integrate it with the gradebook and the moodle philosopy. Post title: Wiki Module Headings problems
Post description: Hi All, I've just started using Moodle, so I am still a bit new to the whole thing. I'm planning on using the Wiki module to create a planning document. However, I've bumped into an issue with regard to the formatting, particularly with headings and subheadings. According to all the documentation, if I put two equal signs around the text that I want as a main heading, it should be done automatically. However, when I do that, it seems as if the wikiwords is getting the signal to turn it into "preserve formatting" ie. everything inside the equals signs appear in "courier" or some sort of typewriter-based font. It's a minor annoyance, I know... but I'm wondering if I shouldn't just use the straight up HTML only feature. Suggestions?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Double-editing the wiki
Post description: What if two (or more) people are editing the wiki at the same time?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: ...which ever one saves last will be the most recent version! Neither would have each other's edits while they were working, so something would get lost in the newest version. But, you can always look back to the previous versions. This only effects the page that is being edited, not the entire wiki.
Comment 2: Hey! I just discovered that its actually much smarter than I thought! What happens is this. If I open a version for editing, and before I save, someone else saves a new copy, I won't be able to save mine. It will tell me to use the 'back' button on my browser and cut my changes out of the editor. Then I can open the new copy and reapply my changes. mike

Forum Post: 
Post title: Develop 5 FAQs
Post description: 1)Q. Can an 18-year-old student excuse his/her own absences? A. yes 2)Q. can an 18-year-old student leave the school campus at his/her discretion? A. yes, but only with a valid excuse. 3)Q. Do parents and legal guardians retain their educational rights if the 18-year-old student still lives in their house? Who ultimately makes the final decisons? A. No, Even though the student may still live with the parents or legal guardians and is claimed as a dependent, parents or legal guardians only have access to records, but can no longer make any decisons for the students. 4)Q. If an 18-year-old student needs to be transported to the hospital for further medical treatment and is denying treatment, can that student make the final determination or should his/her parent be contacted? A. Since the student is now considered an adult, he/she has the right to make the decision to refuse treatment. 5)Q. Can parents or legal guardians have access to their child's student records even after the child turns 18 years of age or becomes an emancipated minor? A. As long as the parents or legal guardians claim the child as a dependent on their federal income taxes, they retain the right to access their child's student records.

Post title: Individual mode, teacher/non editing teacher can't edit student pages
Post description: In Moodle 2.5 the non-editing teacher and teacher roles could edit student pages when a wiki was running in Individual mode.  We used a wiki with separate groups, in Individual mode, to allow teachers to write notes about each student.  In Separate groups mode, the teacher had a drop-down menu on the left hand side of the page that displayed their group name, and the list of students within it.  Clicking on the student name took you to a page for that student, that you could then edit. Since our upgrade to 2.7, the teacher and non-editing teacher can view the page, but cannot edit it. I’m assuming that this is a bug that got fixed, but I can’t find a tracker item for it.  For us, it was a feature, and one we’d dearly like to get back! Any suggestions from the Moodle community?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ongoing assignments with infinite accountability.
Post description: I am running a translation class, where the students progressively will (I hope) revise their translations of Vergil's Aeneid (or at least the parts on the AP syllabus). I want them weekly to submit their latest translations including the new lines for the next week, but also any revisions they make to their previous efforts. I want to be able to see any changes they make, and to be able to trace any versions back to their original efforts, in case I suspect plagiarism. I considered using the multiple file option of the assignment task, and allow them to resubmit any number of new files (versions), but it seems that a better option might be to use the wiki and have history to show me the versions. A couple of issues occur to me: Will I get notifications when they change things? And will this be too much, if they edit online? Is it possible to compare arbitrary versions of a page, like on mediawiki, or is it just two sequential versions? Can I take a snapshot on the due date, to be sure that assignments are properly characterized as on-time or late? Is this the best way to do all this?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Did no one have an opinion on this question?
Comment 2: 1. The wiki won't send you notifications, but it will keep a record of changes and the times. 2. I believe you can compare any two versions (or at least any past version with the present) 3. You can go to the last edit made on the due date and see the work done. The wiki module hasn't totally impressed me and I hear it will be getting a big update in Moodle 2.0. You cold have them work on a wiki and then every week have them copy the current version and paste it into an online text asasignment.
Comment 3: Yes I agree that a wiki is your best bet for managing successive versions. We use OU Wiki because the NanoGong HTMLArea works with it (Moodle 1.93 - you should test this first in other versions) allowing audio annotations which might be useful for translation feedback. The wiki allows comparisons between any two previous versions (not just sequential versions), and it also allows you to revert to any previous version. The only downside is that it doesn't have a mechanism for assessment/grading, but then perhaps taking a snapshot copy and submitting it in a proper assignment might be better as it would generate a gradebook entry. An alternative to the wiki might be a forum (which is gradable), but this would only be practical for shorter texts. Regards, Mike Smith, Brisbane
Comment 4: Hi - We are stuggling to decide which Wiki to use. One of my technology collegues refuses to use the existing Moodle Wiki at all. I'm wondering if it makes sense to use OU Wiki or DF Wiki at this point. Can you explain more about why you chose OU Wik? Will you switch when 2.0 comes out? Thanks very much for your thoughts.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki links do not turn blue, they vanish into plain text when they exist
Post description: I'm running Moodle 2.2 and testing out the Wiki for use in classes next week.  I'm running TeX and algebra filters. The wiki works fine, but links vanish into plain text from red once they exist rather than turning blue.  The links work fine if one can then find them. Is there a simple setting or fix to this?  I have not been able to search and find something on this problem. Many thanks!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ted, Does this mean that all your links in all blocks turn back to grey text after you have visited them? If that were the case your theming could be better! I'm not a Wiki expect but it sounds to me as if the css theme settings for links aren't doing you any favours. If the colour (color) setting for a:visited is the same as your ordinary text then they will certainly turn to plain text after the page is defined. If you are using Chrome browser then you can right-click (or CTRL-click) one such link and choose Inspect element to see what the settings are. You should also be able to change the colour temporarily here to see what effect that has. Similar things are available in in Firefox if you have Firebug installed as an add-on. To make permanent changes you need to edit the css. But if you do that in the theme's style.css you may affect all links. You can also work with the wiki's style.css in /mod/wiki/style.css. You should not open this file in a word processer such as Word, but in a text editor or a special css editor (a text editor will do fine). Start by saving a spare copy of this file (in case of disasters). Find the entry that begins: a.wiki_newentry and replace it with: .text_to_html a:link { color:purple !important; } a.wiki_newentry:link { color:deeppink !important; font-style: italic; } a.wiki_newentry:visited { color:turquoise !important; } Save the file and refresh the page. Do you get strange colours now? This should allow you to narrow down what you want. But note, you may also have to go into the Admin settings -->Theme settings and switch on Designer mode, otherwise you may not see the changes. This is one of many good reasons for not doing this on a live site, it will slow the site down. Hope this helps a bit. --John

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki doesn't save when set to student, visible groups in 1.7
Post description: I've just been using the standard wiki with a class of students writing essay plans and they have run into trouble saving their work. One student received a message saying that he couldn't save his wiki because another student was working on it and lost what he'd been writing, another student ended up with someone elses' work on her wiki page and several only had part of their work saved. Is this normal when many people try to save concurrently under this setup, or is it a new problem with 1.7? Matt
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Matt, several students can work on the same wiki at the same time so long as they are all working on different pages (all pages must have a unique name otherwise links will be created e.g in your case if they all tried to create a page called essay plan, only the first one to save would create the page and everyone else would create links to that page....) I have found that it is best to create the first page of the wiki and include every students name in [] brackets so that when they click on the ? after their name a unique page is created in their name. If they add further pages to their page each page name should be unique, so perhaps get them to add their student number or initials to the page name. Hope this helps. Nigel
Comment 2: Thanks Nigel, that makes a lot of sense. I kind of assumed that when I set it to 'student wiki' that it would make one wiki page for each student automatically as suggested by the fact that the drop-down contains all of the students names and that was more or less what the pop-up help thing suggested. Iwould expect to have to use your technique if I had set it to 'groups' and 'No groups'. Did I misinterpret this?
Comment 3: Matt, You are corrcect, if you set Type to Student then they should each have their own Wiki. I have been doing it this way for ages as a way of providing student feedback. I set type to student and group mode to no groups. This then ensures that the students cannot see each others entries.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Exporting data from a Wiki
Post description: Can data from a table on a Wiki page be exported as CSV (text separated
by commas or tabs)? I have the following problem. We have a project
where it is necessary that all people participating in the creation of
materials can keep track of the codes and names given to documents that
are created by other members of the team. This is necessary because we
want to build some sort of database with information about the
documents and the documents must have a unique code number. People who
create new documents must know whether the code already exists for a
particular document and assign a higher number if this is the case. Excel files work very well for this purpose but the great inconvenience
is that one must download them and upload them again once they are
modified. Since there might be many people working at the same time
that might be a problem. I thought that creating a table on a Wiki
could be a good solution. And here is the reason for my question. Every
once in a while we would like to export the data in the table to be
able to feed it into an excel file or perhaps some data base aplication
but I don't know whether this is possible with a Wiki. Does anybody know the answer to this question? If this is not possible,
does anybody know of some possible solution to this problem? Thanks very much. Josep M.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I haven't tried to export a large table but I have exported wikis containing tables into HTML and then copied the tables in an excel file without any problem. The problem, though, was more about filling in the table in the first place as some people (students in my case) may prefer to have 'ready-made' cells rather than having to type the '|' themselves. Françoise
Comment 2: I'm showing my ignorance, but how does one do that. How does one export a table from an HTML document to an excel file? Thanks. Josep M.
Comment 3: Just highlight the table(making sure that all the cells are highlighted), copy to the clipboard and paste into an Excel worksheet. Françoise
Comment 4: Thanks a lot, Françoise, I didn't think it was going to be that simple, but your solution does work rather well. Somebody else on a different forum suggested also using the data > import data > web query option in Excel. That didn't work, however, probably because the page is within my Moodle site and it needs a password to access it. Josep M.
Comment 5: I tried what you say but the presentation is wrong in excel (see next example). I'm working on macintosh (Safari 2, Firefox 1, Firefox 1.5, excel 2004). For example, for the following table in the wiki: Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 row 1 col 1 row 1 col 2 row 1 col 3 row 2 col 1 row 2 col 2 row 2 col 3 row 3 col 1 row 3 col 2 row 3 col 3 row 4 col 1 row 4 col 2 row 4 col 3 the result with a copy/paste in excel is: Title 1 Title 2 Title 3 row 1 col 1 row 1 col 2    row 1 col 3 row 2 col 1    row 2 col 2 row 2 col 3 row 3 col 1    row 3 col 2 row 3 col 3 row 4 col 1    row 4 col 2 row 4 col 3 After the first cell of each row, a return is added. So the presentation of the table is wrong. Perhaps, may be from the coding of the return on macintosh which is different on windows. What do you think about that ? Last minute : the problem is solved using internet explorer. However, microsoft stopped the development of IE on macintosh since few years. So, I would like that the problem will solve with a another web browser like Firefox. Thanks in advance for your help. Christian
Comment 6: Hola Josep Mª, keep you data on the wiki ( a dfwiki of course ), if you need if I can provide you with a way to save the content of a wiki page to an html file (that you will be able to import from excel or open office ), and a way to import html data into a wiki page. This way you'll have a two way comunication tool. Wold this solve your needs? Ludo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Creating an Initial Page in a Student Wiki
Post description: I'm working in 1.9.2, and I can't get an initial page to appear in student wikis. What I'm after is simple, so I'm stumped.....I want each student to see a list of 10 questions when they open up their individual wiki page. I have the list of 10 questions, and I thought it would be a simple matter to "create an initial page", and designate the 10 question file as the initial page. But when I do, I get a blank screen....nothing on it whatsoever. I know I'm missing something simple....but my brain is fried. Help, please!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I'm not sure that I can solve your problem, Jim, but I have done what you are trying to do before when creating a simple ePortfolio. I created the page in a Wiki, toggled to the html code and then copied and pasted this into a Word document. I saved this as Text Only and left off the extension (as the final wiki used this file name as the name of each student's wiki). I uploaded this into Files and then created the new Wiki, selecting this file to create the initial page. It worked for me..... regards, Kate
Comment 2: Unfortunately, the current erfurtwiki (I assume that is what you are using, but if it is not you need to let us know that ASAP) is really not adequately documented and the fact that a new wiki has been adopted does not encourage investing time in the current one. One of the sources of continuing confusion with respect to student wikis is that once the teacher creates the student wiki, and attempt to edit the wiki's first page will only impact the teacher's instance. Can't tell if this is what you are confronted with, but this is often the source of confusion. As Kate suggests, there is a method that is, well, a bit obscured for creating student wikis that allows for multiple pages, but it also might help you to see the difference.
Comment 3: We've run into that problem as well -- faculty can't edit a "student" wiki. We've had to use these 'not too intuitive' settings -- "group" wiki set to "no groups". There doesn't seem to be any way to edit wiki type once it's been set up... best to you, deb
Comment 4: Hi Jim you have probably solved or given up on this one, but I had a similar problem and eventually worked it out. You do indeed set up an initial folder, with one or more of the pages that you would like the wiki to be pre-populated with in that folder. The files must be text format but they should have no file extension. You then upload them to wherever you need, create the wiki activity, select the specific file you want to start with. All pages created with the links in square brackets work because they point to files with identical names (e.g. [foo] will successfully create and link to a file called foo, but not one called foo.txt. So obvious once I thought about it but at least it is here for anyone else searching on this problem. Cheers Ed

Post title: Any Good Example of Wiki
Post description: I am unable to use wiki effectively. Is there any good example to look at? Can it be effectively used as wikipedia?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Bernie Dodge of San Diego State University has defined seven Wiki design patterns that can be used in particular situations. Take a look at the NECC 2006 presentation by Dan McDowell . Dan (a history teacher) presents several successful Wiki projects that he has implemented using the pattern approach.
Comment 2: Unfortunately, the Wiki design patterns page appears to be broken (spits out php errors).
Comment 3: It's too bad -- it was a good resource. He may have moved it somewhere, but I can't find it. I think webquest.org is the new home for all this material, but I can't find anything specifically related to wiki design patterns on the site. It may be that the wiki design patterns have been subsumed by WebQuest design patterns , which are more general (they don't assume a wiki implementation, butcould be implemented using wiki).
Comment 4: Wiki design pattern link is not working. NECC 2006 presentation by Dan McDowell is ok. But is it designed by moodle wiki. I would like to know, can we use powerful wikipedia as a part of moodle, if so how? I would like the community to categorise and create their own content of interest.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki Locking When in Edit Mode
Post description: One of things I wish the wiki editor had and would really like to see implemented is for the editor to lock the wiki when someone clicks the Edit link so that it can't be edited by someone else at the same time.  As it stands now (in 1.7) that doesn't happen and so a person may lose a significant amount of work because someone else has edited the wiki and saved their changes before the first person finishes what s/he is doing.  It would also be nice if there was a way to automatically update (or save) the wiki when it is being edited -- just in case a person forgets (as I did) to save changes periodically.  I lost nearly two hours of work because someone else in my group made a smalll change in our wiki.  Teaches me a lesson , but also prompted this "wish list item." Mike Ryan
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: The absence of this feature makes this Wiki almost unusable for students. I know it is common, but this is a place where Moodle can differentiate itself.
Comment 2: I have the same problem : I don't work directly on the wiki anymore, because of the risk losing all my work. Lot's of troubles ! But there is something I don't understand : in the Moodle demo site ( http://demo.moodle.org/ ), if I try to edit a wiki page which is already edited by somebody else, then the page is locked and I get the following message : " This page is being edited by Student Demo. They began editing at (day, date, hour) and still have the window open as of (date, hour). You need to wait for them to finish before you can edit this page." How does this feature work in the demo, and not in "my" moodle (1.7) ? Does anybody knows if there is a way to get this ? Somebody asked a similar question in january ( Wiki Wipeout Due to Posting Collisions ), seems to have no answer, although it's a main feature, no ? Thanxs

Forum Post: 
Post title: Student can upload file into teacher's wiki - is that normal?
Post description: Using my 'dummy student', I was able to upload a file into the teacher wiki. I am not sure whether I like it or not... Does this mean that any one can upload anything in somebody else's wiki? (if they can view it, that is). Françoise
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You shouldn't have been able to do that. How did you do that? mike
Comment 2: That's what I thought... How did I do it? Well, I have the habit of clicking on everything I see until I know a program inside out (but I can't program...). So I logged on as a student (my 'dummy student'), had a look at the teacher wiki I had created and started clicking on any clickable thing. On one of the pages, I (as the teacher) had attached a couple of files. When students view that page, there is a link at the bottom of it: This page has attachments (or something like that). If the student clicks on the link, it brings her to the attachment page, which gives her the possibility to upload a file, change its name and write a comment.
Comment 3: Thanks for finding that. I'll fix it. You should be able to handle any attachments in the same way. I attach and download Word documents all the time. The way you describe it, it sounds like something your local browser is doing. In both Firefox and IE , I just open it (not save) when I click on it. If I save it, it works fine too. I know that Windows will add extra '[1]' charcters to files that it downloads from email attachments if they have identical names when they come into Outlook. Perhaps your browser is set similarly?

Forum Post: 
Post title: Best wiki for Moodle 2.0?
Post description: I have been eargerly awaiting our installation of Moodle 2.0 because I was looking forward to the wiki upgrade - but feel a bit lost.  I am guessing that our administrator installed the default wiki inside of Moodle (which is a derivative of nwiki, right?) Is there a place I can go to read documentation on the wiki.  Back in 1.7 we had installed dfwiki and while there were certainly some usability and stability issues that concerned us, but there were many features I liked - I figured that with Moodle 2.0 the wiki that had been integrated would have been an improved version of the original dfwiki.  It appears to me that the current Moodle wiki (wiki2?) actually now has less functionality than the previous ewiki ... (i.e. can not support attachments).  It also does not seem to include the one feature that I know our users (students and faculty) really want - the ability to subscribe to a page - which dfwiki had.  Where can I go to read up on differences between wiki2 and ou wiki?  And is there a current roadmap for enhancements of wiki2?  I am still a bit confused about where Moodle is heading with regards to wikis (which I think are fundamental tools if you are trying to teach in a social constructive environment.) Many of our faculty go to external appliations (like pbworks) for their wikis now - we would prefer if they kept their learning activities inside our LMS as much as possible so our users have a more consistent experience.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I collected some of the open issues regarding Wiki 2.0 from the tracker here... http://moodle.org/mod/forum/post.php?reply=768009 ...after running into problems using Wiki 2. I second your statement that wikis "are fundamental tools if you are trying to teach in a social constructive environment." Wiki is one of the very coolest and creative features in Moodle and I look forward to using a fully functional Wiki core module inside Moodle 2 soon.

Post title: searching ONLY current wiki version
Post description: consider this scenario in wiki search: the search feature in wiki module searches in all versions of the wiki , but, the search result displays only a link to the latest wiki version (current wiki) only , after the search process, when the user clicks on the result link (wiki link) it would display the current version only and the user may get confused because the current version may not contain the word he was searching for, but when the user navigates to history tab, and goes through old versions of the wiki, he will find the word he was searching for in one (or maybe more) old versions of the wiki (and of course the word will not be highlited for this case so the user would search for it manually). so for this scenario, the result must display links for old versions of the wiki if these versions contain the search word. so I think the search wiki feature is unreasonable if this scenario happens (and it really happened with me), is there a way to search for words ONLY in the current version of wiki and then display the link for this wiki? should I change something in this line of code: if (! isset ( $_REQUEST [ "content" ]) && ( $dquery [ "version" ] = @ $_REQUEST [ "version" ])) { $dquery [ "forced_version" ] = $dquery [ "version" ]; } this line is on mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php file .. thank you so much in advance. P.S. moodle version 1.9.9

Comment 1: Hi Josep Mª! actually is a functionality not implemented yet. I'll try to do it soon. Regards Ludo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Migrating separate student wiki to wiki 2.0... big time dilemma
Post description: In a point in time Skodak decided not not support separate student wikis... and all the UPC team exclaimed "Yay!" and we had a beer to celebrate it. Separate student wikis create weird dilemmas to deal with, because students enroll and unenroll. And yet, pedagogically, there is no point to have a non collaborative wiki going on. So we don't support it... Yay! But... there are separate student wikis out there in Moodle 1.x wikis and even on nwiki setups. So... We cannot throw away that content or somebody will be mad at me. The proposed solution : - we create a group with the teacher(s) and the student owner of the wiki, and place the content there.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: My reasoning was that other modules also need this mode of operation - "separate students". Since 1.9 we have the groupings that were designed to extend the uses of groups and allow exactly this. It is still marked as experimental, but groupings will be enabled in all 2.0 (only groupmemebrsonly will be kept experimental). The workflow would be pretty simple, first go to group admin UI and let Moodle create new grouping with one group for each user in the course. Then create a new wiki and set the grouping there. Everybody will have his/her own wiki. This should be fairly easy for upgrades too. If we decide to implement separate student wikis the problems are: * a lot more access control + more complex db structure * we need new UI for user selection so that teachers may actually access the user wikis * we need to handle cases where users are enrolled/unenrolled in the middle of the course * we can not change the mode of wiki from user to group * other modules need to do the same in order to keep consistency The coding and maintenance costs would be higher, on the other hand we would have a feature that probably no other wiki has and probably very few ppl use in the real life, also the UI would be cluttered with extra controls and the wiki would not be consistent with the rest of our modules. I personally think we should stop abusing modules for something they are not designed for, wiki is by definition a collaboration tool, so we should imo encourage group work in wiki and just describe potential workaround in case somebody really wants to use them in a different way. If somebody needs a personal notepad with wiki syntax support, it could be a My Moodle(dashboard) block. We should also concentrate on grading of work done by students in wikis, this could be best done as new gradebook reports that other modules may share. Another example is the Forum module, it could be hacked to support one-on-one teacher-student communication, but it would be an ugly hack with many problems, so instead I created the new consultation module. News forum type is yet another example of problematic - there are so many differences in news and forum discussions that it will be significantly easier to create News module instead of trying to fix the current new forum subtype. We had a little disagreement with Martin over this issue, unfortunately I do not remember if I managed to persuade hit the last time we discussed this ;-)
Comment 2: As I said Petr... Yay! For me the only issue is the migration, so no data gets lost, and I think we have pretty much covered it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki and Excel
Post description: One of my science teachers wants to have an excel spreadsheet pasted into a wiki for students to enter data.  However, when I paste it in the wiki, the excel formulas don't work. We cant use Google Docs, because it is blocked by our district filter.  Any ideas?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I guess I am surprised that you thought the excel formulas would work, but have you thought about asking the district to allow you to access google docs either by just killing the blacklist entry or via a district google domain ? Of course if district IT refused you could a) simply tunnel to your own proxy or b) just have the students access google docs on their iPhones - LOL There is the ability to do calculation with asciimath, and given some time you could kludge together a calculated table - if you want to explore that install asciimath and check out the calculator
Comment 2: I should have worded that differently.  Is there anyway to embedd an excel spreadsheet, so it can be edited. Thanks for your input.
Comment 3: I mentioned some possible ways to provide access to an online spreadsheet, but I don't know of any way to make excel specifically available via the web save perhaps through citrix. You could use another webbased app or even use thegoogle php api to do a editable noodle accessible spreadsheet, but that would be a gooddeal of work. I do believe that talking to your district IT staff about an exception for google docs or at least an exception for a google app district domain is a quick and easy way to address having access to googledocs. Btw , remember that there are conversion issues that arise moving back and forth from googledoccs to excel
Comment 4: I should mention, since you did refernce excel. That you can publish excel spreadsheets as webdocs, but then you have to have ie to use them. There are quite a few resources on the web explaining how to move an excel spreadsheet to php and mysql , and if you have moodle you likely have access to both - faced with providing access to google docs or integration of your moodle with google apps as opposed to developing a php app or porting simple php spreadsheet, there is no telling what your helpful IT and EdTech staff might do.
Comment 5: Thank you for your time and information.  I will share it with our IT.
Comment 6: Hi Deb, Two suggested work arounds. The first way would be a bit clunky if you had lots of students, but you could enable binary files, and upload a 'starter' Excel spreadsheet. Students would have to take turns to download the spreadsheet, add their dadta, and re-upload. At least the wiki organises things with date and time stamps so that the latest version could be downloaded and editted. Another alternative would be to have a table in your wiki with the format you have in the spreadsheet and have all the students enter the data. When all the data has been enetered you upload the spreadsheet with the formulas and they copy and paste the data from the wiki into it. Cheers, Sally Mack

Post title: Editing a Wiki as a Guest
Post description: Greetings all, I hope you can help me. I am using Moodle 2.2 and can not seem to get guests to be able to edit a wiki. I have tried altering some of the wiki permission settings but that doesn't work. I have also read in the Feedback module forum that it will not allow guests to complete a survey in the Feedback module. Is there any way around this? It is really important to us to be able to have guests being able to edit wikis and complete Feedback surveys. Kind Regards, Marcel
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi there. Guests can complete feedback surveys on the front page if you follow the appropriate settings - http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Feedback_FAQ However, guests can't edit wikis. There are certain things that the guest role does not allow and wiki editing is one - see the documentation here http://docs.moodle.org/22/en/Guest_role The workaround is to make a real account -call it "visitor"; let your guests know the password and let them edit using that.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Custom CSS for edit-page in Wiki
Post description: Hi, I want to change the CSS for all wikis on my site but nothing else. This Post helped me change the style of the view.php tab. This CSS works for one single page: `.cmid-3547 h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` This works for all wikis: `#page-mod-wiki-view h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` But it only affects the veiw.php-tab. When I edit a page it looks different. How can I change the edit.php-tab as well? I tried this: `#page-mod-wiki-view, #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;}` Unfortunately this changed the menu and other elements as well.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Is it just the h3 size you want to change? What version of Moodle are you using?
Comment 2: I use Moodle 3.11.12 and the Boost Theme. I don't like how the Wiki looks in Boost and want it to look more like Wikipedia. So these are all my changes so far: `.cmid-3547 h3 {` `font-weight: 400;` `font-size: 1.8em;` `margin-bottom: 0.5em;` `border-bottom: 1px solid #b2b2b2;` `padding-bottom: 3px;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 .wiki_headingtitle h3 {` `font-weight: normal;` `border-bottom: none;` `padding-bottom: 0;` `margin-bottom: 0;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 h4 {` `font-weight: 300;` `font-size: 1.5em;` `margin-bottom: 0.25em;` `border-bottom: 1px solid #b2b2b2;` `padding-bottom: 3px;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 h5 {` `font-weight: 600;` `font-size: 1.2em;` `margin-bottom: 0.25em;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 img {` `max-width: 100%;` `height: auto;` `}` `` `.cmid-3547 code {` `font-size: 100%;` `}`
Comment 3: If you inspect the page, you will see html code similar to body id="page-mod-wiki-edit" class=" etc You need to replace the id with a # and the class with a . so the selector is #page-mod-wiki-edit for the edit page and #page-mod-wiki-view for the view page any changes to CSS will affect everything on that page so you need to be more specific. You have specified a particular wiki, .cmid-3547 - so changes will only affect that one wiki and not all wikis on your Moodle. but . cmid-3547 h3 will affect all h3 tags on the page. If you only want to target the elements on the edit page, eg. h3 tags, then use #page-mod-wiki-edit.cmid-3547 #region-main h3 {
Comment 4: Thank a lot. I found the mistake in my original code. WRONG: #page-mod-wiki-view, #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;} Correct: #page-mod-wiki-view h3 , #page-mod-wiki-edit h3 {font-size: 1.8em;} That's why it was styling all elements on the page. Here is my complete Custom CSS for the Wiki Activity: https://github.com/margomius/moodle-wiki-custom-css

Post title: Does DFWiki support group mode now?
Post description: DFWiki is the only one that can meet the demands of teachers in our school. However, It is a pity that teachers fail to use GROUP function although they have set it up when creating a DFWiki  in MOODLE. The DFWiki version in our MOODLE is rev2005111501. Any suggestions or news will be greatly appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Thank you Alexander , we'll take a look in the GROUP mode. I'll give news soon. Regards Marc
Comment 2: Any news on support of groups with dfwiki yet?
Comment 3: Yes, we have allready implemented the groups in dfwiki, in a few days we'll sqeeze it into the new release (we have 3 dev lines that need integration). Hold on til, say, next tuesday.. Ludo
Comment 4: Am testing dfwiki release that supports groups and am wondering about
the matrix of groups that exists for efurt wiki in Moodle - I notice
when setting up dfwiki that I do not have the option to set up a type,
(Teacher, Groups, Student) - so to get individual wikis for each
student I would need to put each of them in their own group of 1,
correct?
Comment 5: Yes, groupmode in dfwiki works like this. You have a dfwiki for each group, so if you want a dfwiki for each student, you have to activate the group mode and put each student in a diferent group.
Comment 6: So, if I understand you correctly (since Moodle does not support subgroups yet), you would not be able to use larger group and individual group wikis with dfwiki in the same course - have dfwiki developers looked into the way efurt wiki handled this with "types" of wikis in coordination with Moodle groups? thanks-
Comment 7: Hi Kristin, maybe dfwiki behaves diferent from ewiki in some aspects. I do believe in the "personal wiki" aproach, but since the implementation of this is "separate wiki's" I don't really like it. In the future I stand for working in a desing of a personal wiki within a server /class/group wide wiki scope, each student would have permision wrigths over its own pages (read/write/comment/etc)... but I'll start to work on this when dfwiki will be integrated into moodle... Martin has the ball on his roof! Ciao Ludo

Forum Post: 
Post title: contribution: PostgreSQL tables for WIKI
Post description: Where can we contribute ? maybe a dumb question, sorry didn't had the time to read all the dev. info. mod/wiki/db/postgres7. sql Written by Pim Koeman, Wittenborg-university, Deventer, The Netherlands the moodle_ prefix can be replaced by any prefix Warning : compiles on postgres 7.4 untested on moodle functionality --// cut here //-- CREATE SEQUENCE moodle_wiki_id_seq INCREMENT 1  START 1; CREATE SEQUENCE moodle_wiki_entries_id_seq INCREMENT 1  START 1; CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki ( id int NOT NULL default nextval('moodle_wiki_id_seq'::text), course int NOT NULL default 0, name varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', summary text NOT NULL, pagename varchar(255) default NULL, wtype varchar(255) NOT NULL default 'group', ewikiprinttitle int NOT NULL default 1, htmlmode int NOT NULL default 0, ewikiacceptbinary int NOT NULL default 0, CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki_entries ( id int NOT NULL default nextval('moodle_wiki_entries_id_seq'::text), wikiid int NOT NULL default 0, course int NOT NULL default 0, groupid int NOT NULL default 0, userid int NOT NULL default 0, pagename varchar(255) NOT NULL default '', timemodified int NOT NULL default 0, PRIMARY KEY  (id) ); CREATE TABLE moodle_wiki_pages ( pagename VARCHAR(160) NOT NULL, version int NOT NULL DEFAULT 0, flags int DEFAULT 0, content TEXT, author VARCHAR(100) DEFAULT 'ewiki', created int DEFAULT 0, lastmodified int DEFAULT 0, refs TEXT, meta TEXT, hits int DEFAULT 0, wiki int NOT NULL, PRIMARY KEY (pagename, version, wiki) );
Comments associated with the post:

Forum Post: Post title: Wikiexport: some questions Post description: Dear wiki developers, we are developing virtual environment for university thesis writing and thesis supervising for Finnish university students and their supervisors. We think Moodle would be probably best platform to our environment and we are starting our own development work. We are very interested about Wiki and its development like dfWiki. In dfwiki there seems to be some very interested features. Wikiexport is important feature to our project. So, I am asking your help in following questions: 1) When exporting Wikipages, is it possible to include ALL links in Wiki? We have tested Moodle's current Erfurt Wiki, and there is a problem because you can only import "downward" links. Referring links (breadcrumb trails) are not included when we have tested wikiexport. So if you look your exported wikipages in browser, you can go from one wikipage to another, but you cannot come back via wiki's links. 2) It would be useful to export wikis to pdf- or rtf. Is anyone developing solutions to this? 3) When exporting wikipages to html/pdf/rtf, it would be also useful to replace Wiki's CamelLetters with normal text. Is there solutions to this? TIA , Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Hi Jani, first of all wiki (efurt Wifi) and dfwiki are completelly diferent modules and they almost don't share code ( only in the backward compatibility ewiki editor mode ). In dfwiki we have the import / export feature and the backup/restore feature wich integrates into the moodle backup system. I prefer the import export feature because it allows me to replicate wiki contets to any course or moodle installation. In the next two weeks we'll release a new dfwiki feature that will allow us to import data from old efurtwikis to dfwiki (extracting it from the moodle backup files). PDF and XHTML export is scheduled for next month. If you use dfwiki in html editor or dfwiki editor mode you don't need to use CamelCase, you simply use double brackets for links . Regards Marc Comment 2: Hi Marc, thanks a lot! We are looking forward about this pdf export - it sounds really interesting. In dfWiki XHTML export, is there solution to link export problem I described in my first message?  I have been testing dfWiki at your Moodle site's sandbox and it looks really great! regards Jani Comment 3: There's allways the option of creating page synonims in dfwiki so CamelCase can become "Camel Case" and a search an replace tool can be used to change CamelCase links to Camel Case or Camel Case.. Regards Marc Label:

Soooo, is there a piece of SQL code somewhere that could be run to create the New Wiki tables in the MySQL database? If not, is there a description of the table fields so that I can create it manually? Any other ideas? TA MarkPea

Forum Post: Post title: Severe performance issues after import/export to latest dfWiki Post description: Hey all, I recently upgraded my dfWIki whose pages were created using a 'pre-export feature' version of dfWiki. I upgraded to the recent version of dfWiki I exported my current wiki pages (no history) I loaded up the new server and imported that the import seemed to work fine -  all the pages were there. Two problems remained, however: formatting - pages created with the wysiwyg viewer lost the carraige returns between lines so all the text runs together. (~1000 pages - yikes!) Performance - each page takes 30sec to load now. The performance issue is the real drawback - the site is very hard to study from now. Has anyone else had similar issues? any idea how to fix this?  I had originally imported the whole wiki with all the historical versions of all the pages - then, thinking that was the source of the slowdown, i recreated the wiki using just the latest version of each page - but still have the same problem. thanks for any help you can offer! -jon Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: HI Jon, thank you for your feedback... We'll get to it rigth now. Juan and antonio will contact with you to find out what's going on. Can you send us the backup you used to import them on dfwiki to hack a litle. Regards Ludo. Comment 2: Hi John, pleas send me your backup to juancastanolpz@hotmail.com and I'll take a look at it. Juan Comment 3: Juan, I am interested to hear if you have been able to reporduce the problem. happy holidays! -jon Comment 4: Yes, we're working on it. Happy hollidays, Juan Comment 5: Hello John, I've been investigating on it and I've found out that the block navigator takes too time to load when there are a lot of pages. Try to delete this block and tell me if it works better. Juan Comment 6: that was it! thank you very much for your help! now we can at least use the thing with limited navigation till a solution is found. great news. -jon Comment 7: Perfect! Anyway now you can use the list of pages block, that is much faster than the navigator. Tell me if you can manage please. Thanks for your testing. Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki confusion
Post description: I have lots of questions! 1. When I go to export a wiki, the resulting zip file is empty. 2. My other option is to put it in a module directory. Where/what is that? 3. Can someone point me to a help file/site/something that actually explains what a wiki is to someone who has NO idea? I'm trying to explain it to teachers and while I think I understand it, I'm at a complete loss to *explain* it and all the bits I've seen use very unfamiliar vocabulary to me (I think it's a special wiki dialect, I'm not sure). 4. other modules - every once in a while I see mention of other modules in development and yet when i go into the Moodle modules site it's all the same old stuff. Is there somewhere else I should be looking for Moodle modules? Thanks for any and all suggestions!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Sarah, I have lots of questions about wiki as well, so I can only answer #3 and #4. I hope to hear some other answers, too. 3. There is no documentation that I can find about wiki in the official documentation or Matt Riordan's Teacher Manual 1.3. You might contact him and see if he has a new version 1.4 coming out and could he send you an early draft. To explain wiki to other teachers and students, I simply call it a "group document". In other words, a group of people can individually edit and re-edit the content. 4. New modules (such as Form, blog , etc.) under development are mostly available in the nightly build of Moodle version 1.5dev. If you have a separate server which you reserve exclusively for experimenting, then you can go to Downloads and try this one. It is unstable, which is why they are not available for general download yet. A few modules which have been under development for a while and are fairly stable (Book, Hotpot, Questionnaire) are available for special download under Add-on Modules in the Download section. By the way, I have another question about wikis. If two or more people edit a wiki at the same time and then save it about the same time, what happens? Which version gets saved?
Comment 2: Hi Don, I have an updated manual based on 1.4.1 that I am determined to get out on Friday (the 17th). I am almost embarrassed how long it has taken me to update it, but this has been a busy couple of months. -Matt
Comment 3: This is great news.  I have two groups ready to "wiki", but am not comfortable enough myself to set them off.  I will be lurking on Friday.
Comment 4: "If two or more people edit a wiki at the same time and then save it about the same time, what happens? Which version gets saved?" Only one can save at any given time. The second person gets a message saying that the wiki is being edited by somebody else and can then copy the changes and paste them in the latest version. It actually works pretty well as far as I could see from my students's use of their group wiki (I had 10 group wikis with 3 to 5 students in each group). Françoise
Comment 5: Thanks for the explanation, Francoise. So a wiki requires turn-taking. Student1edit >> Student1save >> Student2edit >> Student2save >> Student3edit... and so on. It is not like a physical blackboard/whiteboard where many contributors can simultaneously make a comment. I wonder if online "whiteboards" operate like wikis or like their physical counterparts. This means when I ask for evaluation comments at the end of my face-to-face class, I should not use a wiki. I should use a forum (with setting to one-person/one-comment). Then everyone can make a comment and save it at the same time.
Comment 6: I'll limit myself to question no. 3: One nice source of info on the wiki phenomenon is the Wikipedia. Their listing for "wiki" can be found at: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wiki It contains some nice tidbits on the etymology of wiki, the underlying wiki philosophy (make it easy to fix mistakes, rather than make it hard to make mistakes) and some of the pros (wonderful collaborative environment) and cons (vandalism) of wikis. Cheers, Mike
Comment 7: On the pros and cons of wiki: it should be used in a high-trust environment. In other words, only have a group work in it *after* they have built trust among themselves or you sense trust has developed. Needless to say, group wikis should often be closed to group members alone. Note also that if a wiki has been accidentally or deliberately messed up, you can go back to an earlier version to start over.
Comment 8: You can set the group wikis as separate and then switched to visible at the end when the wikis are ready for "public view". Other groups can then see every other wikis but cannot edit them. I found it really good to give some space to groups to work together on a project, knowing that nobody else (apart from the teacher) would see it until its completion.
Comment 9: >> You can set the group wikis as separate and then switched to visible... Yes, I agree this is a very powerful procedure. Groups should wrestle with a problem/project independently at first, coming up with their own original responses privately. Then when they are ready to revise and rebuild, it is helpful to see models/results of other groups. Therefore, maybe a step or two before the "end product", we can turn the wiki on publically.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Heads up: Wiki 1.x interwiki disabled by default
Post description: Hi, wiki 1.x (the one distributed as part of Moodle 1.x core), has one undocumented feature: interwiki links. And it has been there, anonymously, since the beginning of the module. Recently we "discovered" ( MDL-19460 ) it was causing some annoyances to pages named "Wiki: whatever" and others, causing the module to automatically redirect to other URLs (interwiki ones). As long as the feature is an undocumented one (and unsupported) we have decided to disable it by default. So starting next weekly build (June 17th 2009) those interwiki links won't be working anymore under Moodle 1.x. In any case, as last resort... if somebody was using such feature it's possible to enable it again by defining: $CFG->wiki_allow_interwiki = true;

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki omitting anchors in external links
Post description: Hello everybody, I want to link to a specific part of an external page like this: http://docs.moodle.org/en/Wikis#Creative_Wiki_practices If I add a link like this inside a wiki page, it links only to the first part of the link ( http://docs.moodle.org/en/Wikis ) but omits the anchor (#Creative_Wiki_practices). (By the way, we have the same problem on this page. Just look at the first link above.) Is there a solution to my problem? Thank you for your answers! Best regards,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: We used to be able to specify anchors within Moodle 1.8.x, e.g. [ https://eureka.westmont.edu/mod/wiki/view.php?id=2848&page=FAQ+-+Students#nopasswd ] . (This is a live, public page.) However, apparently since upgrading to 1.9.2+, when a wiki page is edited either in HTML mode or using WYSIWYG HTML editor, all anchors are stripped from the resulting code, leaving only <a></a> where <a name=nopasswd></a> should be. Previous versions of the page in the mysql database have the proper anchor tags. Anyone else seeing this problem? John Rodkey
Comment 2: I'm having this problem, does anyone know if there was a fix? r.
Comment 3: For the record I discovered the following: HTMLpurifier was casuing this problem. I had to update HTMLPurifier Lite to Version 4 and then I added 
```text
$config->set('Attr', 'EnableID', true);
$config->set('Attr', 'EnableAttrID', true);

to the constructor in HTMLPurifier.php

Anchors work perfectly and the formating of my page is retained!

R.
```

Forum Post: 
Post title: ouwiki templates and images
Post description: I created an ouwiki with some images.  I exported it as a template and then created a new ouwiki and imported this template.  It seems my images are not imported.  I can see the link in the template xml and in the new wiki html, but the img link is broken.  Is this the intended functionality? Thanks Carl
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Carl, I'm the lead developer for ouwiki so I can probably shed some light on your issue. What version of the plugin and Moodle are you using? The most recent version of the plugin for your specific Moodle version should be used to ensure you have all bug fixes etc. These can be downloaded from https://moodle.org/plugins/view.php?plugin=mod_ouwiki - note for ouwiki you should raise questions there or issues on the github project , not on this forum as it's not monitored. If you're having problems with template images you should check they are in the template zip file (assuming the template is a zip file, if it's just xml you are using a version of the plugin that doesn't support images in templates).
Comment 2: I'm using Moodle 2.7 so I'm guessing thats the issue.
Comment 3: Changing the reg expression near line 215 of entirewiki.php from '#<img.*?src="https://moodle.org/pluginfile.php/193/mod_forum/post/1160402/(.*?)".*?/>#' to '#<img.*?src="https://moodle.org/pluginfile.php/193/mod_forum/post/1160402/(.*?)".*?>#' (i.e. removing the closing slash) seems to have solved the problem in Moodle 2.7. For some reason img tags had closing "/" in 2.6 but not in 2.7. Maybe this is a 2.7 bug?

Post title: Uninstalling Nwiki?
Post description: Hi! After i installed Nwiki then the CVS update's didnt work properly anymore so im kinda stuck. How can i uninstall Nwiki or maybe someone can give me ideas how to make CVS update working again? For your information i tried replacing the mod/wiki with the old mod/wiki(default wiki) but updating to nwiki altered the DB tables and the default wiki didnt show up the data correctly anymore. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Tònis, NWiki is not oficial , meaning it is not distributed with the oficial moodle CVS. NWiki REPLACES the /MOODLE/mod/wiki directory this is by request of the BOSS when NWki started being a candidate for wiki module back in Moodle 1.5 ... so when you get a fresh copy from moodle cvs you should delete this directory before copying the bundle into your server . Another option is simpli to re-copy the nwiki distribution after you copy the cvs update (BEFORE you log in as admin) Hope this helps L.

Forum Post: 
Post title: df wiki and groups
Post description: I know this topic has been initiated in other threads but believe the implementation of groups within df wiki needs be addressed in a thread by itself. 1. It appeared from our testing that setting up a wiki to have separate groups kept everyone except group members out of the wiki (including the teacher). In other moodle assignments an instructor is not limited by enabling grouping - which is why you do not put a teacher in a group! 2. Visible groups enabled all others to see other groups' wikis, but also appeared to give them editing priviledges in another groups' wiki. What are the plans for updating dfwiki group features to enable a teacher to be able to view and edit all wikis and to keep the visible group features supported so that if visible groups are used, students can view (but not edit) another group's wiki. We like the group features that were supported in efurt wiki in moodle and would like to see the same type of support (including individual student wikis as has been mentioned in other forum posts). Again - I love dfwiki but the support of groups at this point does not seem to be fully implemented yet - do you have a timeline on any of this - or is there a new version that has been released that addresses some of these issues? We are using dfwiki in our courses now and can not just upload a new version each time it comes out without testing first ....
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Kristin, thank you very much for your feedback and support. Rigth now we are very busy with the migration from dfwiki to wiki (wich is not a trivial issue, cause old wikis and "old" dfwikis have to be converted to the brand new wiki... ) and in adition 4 ( 4!!) developers have just finished their degree project and rigth now are retiring from the project .. maybe one or two of them will get a scholarship to continue with their excelent work (I'm on it!)...

Forum Post: 
Post title: Where or what is the "ImageUploading function"?
Post description: In the wiki editing help page it is mentioned, that in inserting images you can use either [http:://link.to/image.jpg] or the "ImageUploading function". Where or what is this function?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: In the edit view of any wiki page, there is an upload button, following a
field to browse for the relevant documents. It's below the save,
preview and cancel buttons at the bottom of the page. Or at least it is in my wiki! There is an image insert button in the html editor but I think this will only give access to existing site files for students. Only admin / teachers will be able to upload through this route. Hope that helps. Sinéad
Comment 2: I don't see the Upload button, not in "No HTML" or in "Only HTML" modes. I'm the admin of my Moodle, version 1.4.4... With the HTML editor + "traditional" way I could add a picture to the wiki, but I want to use "no HTML" mode, and in that mode the traditional way means a couple of more steps...
Comment 3: Hi, I'm having trouble with the upload function, too. When I change the settings to "allow binary files" the Wiki page dissapears. An error message "page not available at the moment" is created. My students need to upload files to a Wiki -  how can I manage this? Thorsten
Comment 4: I have found the solution: I have changed the setting "binary file" in the administration menu ("page settings" or so) of each coursemembers-wiki (where you can change the settings for read-only, wiki turned off,...). That caused the error and the wikis to disappear. Now, I have changed the setting "allow binary data" in the main setup menu of the wiki. That worked without any problems. Thorsten
Comment 5: As Sinead commented, the imageUploading works for teachers so students will have access to those images the teacher chooses. Students can have access to their own images when they upload those images as described by Sinead (above, message). For them to have access to those images, they type: [internal://ufo.gif] where ufo.gif is the image uploaded.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Ética y Moral
Post description: Ética es la reflexión teórica sobre la moral. La ética es la encargada de discutir y fundamentar reflexivamente ese conjunto de principios o normas que constituyen nuestra moral. Moral es el conjunto de principios, criterios, normas y valores que dirigen nuestro comportamiento. La moral nos hace actuar de una determinada manera y nos permite saber qué debemos hacer en una situación concreta. Es como una especie de brújula que nos orienta, nos dice cuál es el camino a seguir, dirige nuestras acciones en una determinada dirección. La brújula nos indica el camino. En la vida hay que intentar no perder el norte.

Post title: Do not allow entry with @ to render as a mailto link
Post description: I am adding text to a wiki page that has an entry like this: rsync -auvtz --delete -e ssh mmbird@192.168.109.131:/var/moodledata /home I do not want the mmird@192.168.109.131 to render as a mailto: link -- but since Moodle sees the @ it does just that. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Matt - From the help file (/lang/en_utf8/help/wiki/howtowiki.html) if you don't want a WikiWord or a !http://www-address (or [anything] inside square brackets) to become a HyperLink then just prepend it with a exclamation mark or a tilde !NoHyperLink, ~NoHyperLink ![no hyperlink], !! http://nolink.org/

Post title: Unexpected interaction between Wiki and groups

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is it possible for a teacher to protect a Wiki page temporarily to keep people from changing it.
Post description: Hello, Would you know if it is possible to temporarily protect a page in WIKI? That would help teacher of our organization. I do not seem to see any option, neither in the standard Moodle Wiki nor in the OU Wiki. Thanks Imbu
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You can, of course, turn off access to the entire wiki (it will still be available to the teacher), but I don't think you could just freeze one page. I'm pretty sure that an open page is uneditable by any other user, so you could just leave it open somewhere...a crude approach, surely. Otherwise, you can, of course, simply depend on the ability of a wiki to revert to an earlier version to protect existing content. Modifying roles associated with the wiki could also remove editing capabilities for the whole wiki. That's all I've got...good luck!

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki vs. Book
Post description: Hi all - I'm teaching university students and would like them to be able to collaborate in summarizing the content of the lecture so that eventually, they have a resource to prepare for when exam time comes. Would you recommend using a wiki for each lesson , or a book and have each lesson as a chapter? (of course I can use a wiki for entire class or a book for each lesson but that sounds less appealing) Thanks,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi David Wiki would be a better choice because every student can manage to edit one wiki but book is a resource, which a student can't add or edit. Resources only have read permission a student can't interact with it.
Comment 2: At one level, Sakshi is right, but at another, the response does not really answer the question. There is also the idea that data requires its own structure, it demands it essentially. What are you presenting? Static knowledge, googleable content? Informative opinion? Dynamic information? Peer interaction? Wiki or Book, what about forum? Your response also needs to take heed of what you are trying to accomplish in the course - not just the learning outcomes, but the processes involved along the way. That should determine what tools you use. I am currently developing alternate responses to these questions and finding a set of solutions, not just one size fits all. Essentially, Moodle does one job, another tool does another job that Moodle is not designed to do. Seems to be working so far... but we shall see. So let your information and your processes define how you respond to each circumstance.
Comment 3: Thanks to both of you. I want students to be able to contribute their knowledge and basically use wiki as a replacement to their lecture notes. Ideally, at the end of the course, they would be able to print it out and use it as reference. For future courses, I'm still debating if I should give them access to the previous semester material and have them enhance it, or develop it from scratch. A book as you mentioned is more structured, but I definitely want students to own it so seems like I will go with a wiki. I would be interested to see your solution Colin, perhaps you can share.
Comment 4: Perhaps that might be possible David, but for the moment, I am not sure the other tools I am using are not all available outside Australia. Most are, but some are local products - you may have equivalents though. One of the tools is called DayMap, from a Melbourne company. Essentialy an SMS, it also has a small LMS module that is more or less a credible wiki and not a lot else. I am not sure that they will be selling internationally yet but I imagine it won't be long. I am developing a solution that meets our local laws regarding storage of data, as well as promoting positive learning outcomes. It also uses MS-Sharepoint which we are turning into a local repository - so not a lot is going to be stored externally. Moodle is, hopefully, going to be used for resources and online testing, If they can get Mahara up in that environment, then that will be for eportfolio and social networking with other common open source tools for more specific purposes - Wordpress for one. All locally stored and we can develop them to suit our need. One snag, Sharepoint 2013 is not being co-operative right now so the whole strategy could be brought undone by it. As I said, we shall see.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is it possible to add MS Office documents to a Wiki?
Post description: Hi Guys, Can add images and video but can we add MS Office docs as well? Regards, Simon
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes ... I think... Yes, if you copy-paste the contents of a Word document into a Wiki page using the icon "Clipboard with a W" from the second row in the palette of tools. Format from the original document should be preserved. If you see a tab "Files" in the Wiki page, then you are able to add a Word document to a Wiki. I'm using Moodle version 2.2.x or older and I can. Not sure about previous versions. You could also use an external link (such as "share docs" from Google, where students can create documents of various kinds and insert their links in a Wiki. For this, use the "chain link" icon from the third row in the palette of tools. HTH
Comment 2: Sure! Add a piece of text, and link it to your documents. Whilst adding the link you can also upload any type of file. Or do you want to embed the Office file right into the page? Like embedding a pdf via "file resource"? I think thats not possible. Sample
