Forum Post: 
Post title: Are wikis the best way to post documents in moodle?
Post description: Hello all, I am trying to get over 25 procedure documents into our moodle system. Currenlty the documents are all hard copy, with the content being stored in source files (with all sorts of extensions: pdf, word, excel, html, etc). I could just post a pdf of the document but i was hoping for somthing a little more fluid. Would wikis be a good way of keeping 1 source for all the content of a docuement? If so is there a way to break up sections and pages within a wiki so you could print off specific areas instead of the whole document? I understand what wikis are but my experience is limited, Any help would be appreciated. cheers, Mike. PS. if there is a better mod for this I'd love to hear it.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Wiki's would be a good choice. You will have to create the structure by inserting links (doc, section, page) and users will have to navigate it. Printing two consecutive pages could be a real pain. Prototype it first to see if it meets your needs. Also have a look at the third-party Book module . Each one of your original documents would become a chapter in the book, and sections would become sub-chapters. Book is printer-friendly. For an example of a Book, see the Finnish Moodle Teacher's Manual .

Post title: Several students editing a Wiki at the same time?
Post description: Well, I went for it. I learned how to update and add pages to a Wiki. But when I had the students try to do it, it said other students could not update a wiki while someone else was. Fair enough. But how do I use the activity in my classroom of 25 kids? I am hoping someone could tell me how each student can create a page and then link it back to my page and then other pages. Thanks, Phil
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hey there - first up, itsbgreat to see you trying to use a Wiki.  But what you seem to have attempted to do is akin to if you can imagine that you had a car with 30 driving wheels, then how many people could steer it at one time?  At least that's my simplistic analogy. I suggest you come at this from a different angle - instead of thinking I want to use a Wiki, now where can I use it IN MY CLASS?  Why not think of a series of scenarios where you think students could collaborate OUTSIDE the classroom and set a task that requires that to be done, say, before the next lesson . It's 'horses for courses'. Also to lessen the impact of your problem - you could always try creating GROUPS within the Wiki.
Comment 2: Dear Phil
Comment 3: Andy, I guess I am still a little confused. Let's say I structure my wiki to link to several different blank start pages to begin with (as you suggested), how will my students get to the blank pages without clicking on the question mark from the original page? Thanks again for your help, Phil

Forum Post: 
Post title: Warn your students: beware of reload after edit
Post description: Hi there. The current standard wiki and nwiki versions handle pretty well the concurrence issues. You can't edit a page that other student is editing. BUT. If a user edits a page, saves the changes, and then another user changes the pages... if the firts user goes to the toilet and presses reload when he/she comes back.. then the second edition is lost. Is still in the history but no more in the current page. We need to think about how to deal with this ... I've got some ideas but there are more serious issues to fix before. So warn your students about the reload button!!! Ludo

Forum Post: 
Post title: Removing "slash slash" at the bottom
Post description: I've just added my first wiki activity using the built-in wiki for Moodle 1.8.3+ How do I removed the "//" at the bottom of the page? Also, I'd like to change the text in the help link. How do I do that? Is it worth building a wiki now, or should I just wait until I upgrade to Moodle 2.0? Thanks,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: We have v1.9 and also get the '//' at the bottom of each page... and can't help much with your first question. We have wikis and users put up with the //. We are looking forward to having a go with NWiki in 2.0 To edit the help information go to Administration > Language > Language Editing and select the ' Edit help documents ' link. The dropdown provides all the help files, search for the appropriate file e.g. wiki/howtowiki.html... Edit the 'Local modifications' by copying/pasting the content from one of the Master packs. Your local modifications when saved will override the master pack. I hope this helps Teresa

Forum Post: 
Post title: Need your advice!
Post description: I set up a new Moodle 1.9, installed nWiki, and have played around with nWiki – love it. However, when new versions of Moodle are released will I have problems upgrading since the new upgrade will have the original Wiki? I’m guessing that I will have do to the following: 1) Install new Moodle to new directory 2) Move over config.php to new directory 3) Move over new modules that I’ve installed on old directory 4) Move over the 4 directories for nWiki Hopefully it will run again. What happens if/when nWiki becomes the new standard and is included - will it expect the old Wiki data and have problems? Any feedback/suggestions? Thanks in advance,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Perry thanks for using NWiki, this week someone reported a data loss in NWiki preciselly because he upgraded moodle and replaced the nwiki files. I would do it simpler. Just create a folder with only the the contrib modules you installed and your config.php When upgrading moodle cpy th moodle distribution and inmediatelly e-copy the contrib modules of your installation. since nwiki replaces the MOODLE/mod/wiki directory another precaution would be to be sure to remove this directory from de moodle distribution before upgrading. Seems obvious, but is not, be sure to back up ( database and files) eerything before applying the smallest patch. Cheers L.
Comment 2: Thanks for the great advice - I'll do it! My other concern is that nWiki will not become the defacto Wiki in Moodle and another flavor might and this might cause problems later.  But that's just speculation. Thanks again for the great advice. P.S. If this were a live installation with thousands of students, will placing Moodle in Maintenance Mode prevent all kinds of problems when upgrading Moodle?

Forum Post: Post title: CSS and eWiki Post description: I am wanting to define the attributes of a paragraph for editing and viewing wikis. Specifically, I would like to assign a different 'margin-bottom' value that would apply to every "

" paragraph of every wiki. The ewiki readme seems to imply that this is possible (without the use of css markup plugins), but I can't work out where I would insert the style definition. Has anyone done this or something similar? Any help would really be appreciated. Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: This is more of a "themes" issue. You'll need to create your own custom moodle theme and then over-ride the css for paragraphs. I haven't tested this, but something like the following might work: #wiki-view wiki p { margin-bottom: 10px; } --Stuart. Comment 2: Hi Stuart, Thanks for your response. I have a custom theme with a custom css, which is where I tried to insert your code, but did not seem to make a difference. I also stumbled upon the core.css file in the \mod\wiki\ewiki\fragments folder which states in the header "These example style definitions only show how to tweak look of generated WikiPages". I attempted to define "p {..." in this file but made no difference. Comment 3: What version of moodle are you using and is it the standard wiki or have you installed the new wiki (nwiki)? You are right about the css I posted up. It did nothing. Michael Comment 5: After brushing up on your css knowledge I strongly recommend you develop using the Firefox browser with the Firebug addon. The Web Developer addon is also useful. Forum Post: 
Post title: Notification of new comments
Post description: Good evening, My Moodle site will have quite a few wikis, none of which students can edit. But they will be able to Comment on any  page. Is there any way that course teachers and I can be notified of new comments? There are no references to wikis in the Default notification preferences. Thanks, James
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: This is not possible, but there are some trackers about this. For example, this is for the Comments feature on the Assignment page: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-58351
Comment 2: Thanks John. The link you sent is to a thread that started four years ago. I added to it, but see little reason to be optimistic. Cheers.
Comment 3: Hi John, The instructions I created do work now. I get notifications of new comments in Wikis. It's a bit tricky, but it works.
Comment 4: I wrote these instructions for myself yesterday, and to share, once they work. Being notified of a new comment in a wiki. Go to Administration => Reports => Event monitoring rules Click "add a new rule" Fill in the form and Save changes. To be notified of the events you have created rules for, click on Event monitoring page, at the bottom of the page. Select a course from the drop down menu. At the bottom of this page you will see your events that you have not subscribed to. Choose the modules that your rule applies to from the drop down list on the right. If you choose "All instances" all events of that module in that course will trigger a notification. When the event occurs in the chosen place, you will get a notification in the usual way, i.e. your bell icon at the top right will light up. I created comments in several wikis that I created notifications for and didn't get any notification.
Comment 5: Yesterday I created these instructions for myself, and to share, once they work. They are not working at the moment. Being notified of a new comment in a wiki. Go to Administration => Reports => Event monitoring rules Click "add a new rule" Fill in the form and Save changes. A title you'll see in the list of rules Choose Wiki from area to monitor Choose Comment created from Event Write a description if you wish Choose how many of these events need to occur before you are notified Choose how long after the events take place before you are notified Edit the notification if you wish, but keep the default fields. Save changes To be notified of the events you have created rules for, click on Event monitoring page, at the bottom of the page. "Select a course" from the drop down menu. At the bottom of this page you will see your events that you can apply to the chosen course. Choose the wikis that your rule applies to from the drop down list on the right. If you choose "All instances" all new comments on all wikis will trigger a notification. When the event occurs in the chosen place, you will get a notification in the usual way, i.e. your notification bell at the top right will light up. In your Profile, choose Notification preferences. Make sure the check box “Disable notification” is empty. At the bottom of this page, Event notifications => Notification of rule subscriptions. Turn this on. -------- I have followed my steps, created comments in the assigned wikis. No notifications. The only notification I get is that I have created a new rule. Unlike other notifications, it does not have anything clickable in it.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Embedded video
Post description: I am using the Wiki module as a way of posting student video tests so only they and I can see those tests. I load the videos into files by grade level, have the students create their Wiki, then use the hyperlink controls to link the videos to the student's Wiki. The problem I am encountering concerns the way videos are linked to student wikis. My videos are created on Mac as a ".mov" file, and Moodle is automatically embedding them in the body of the wiki. This creates some problems loading each wiki and presents problems if I want to place multiple videos on one wiki. It also messes up student formatting of their wiki. I have tried a number of solutions to try to prevent video embedding, but none (at the code level and otherwise) has yet to work. Anybody have any ideas about how I can still used ".mov" files but prevent automatic embedding? Thanks, Kevin
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: afaik there is no way of doing this. You can use QT Player Pro to Export your .mov to mp4, don't recompress, just "pass through" the video and audio. iTunes can also convert .mov to m4v (same as mp4), use Advanced>Create iPod or iPhone version. But the data rate will be about 1500 kbps. Change the m4v extension to mp4, Moodle seems to like it better. Then the href link to the mp4 will not embed the movie, it will just provide the link to the movie in same window or a new window. At least that's how it works on our install of Moodle. Of course everything needs to be tested on Mac Safari and Firefor, and Win XP/Vista IE and Firefox , but I think it will work.
Comment 2: Thank you for the suggestions! I will give this a try and see if it solves my problem (particularly the suggestion to change the m4v extension).

Forum Post: 
Post title: Blank page when viewing a wiki
Post description: Happy New Year to all. Suddenly, one of my teachers is saying a wiki he created, and has been working with is showing up blank. Upon clicking on the link, the url appears in the address bar (http://domainname/moodle/mod/wiki/view.php?id=2602) and then the spinning wheel goes for 30 seconds (always 30 seconds, I timed it) and then stops with a blank page showing. On the bar at the bottom is the word "done". I can edit the set up of the wiki, I can create a new wiki in this course, and wikis in other courses seem to be working fine. If I understand the log, there is no record of a view of that particular wiki even though I tried numerous times. Any thoughts would be most welcome.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Most probably the wiki page takes to long to process (more than 30 sec.) Can you try these suggestions: If you are the maintainer of the machine go to your php.ini file and adapt max_execution_time = 30 to a higher value. If you can't control the php settings of your webser you can try to put Best is not to make one large wiki page but split them in smaller one's
Comment 2: Herbert, Thanks for responding. I had suspected a time out issue even before I posted. When I arrived at my office this am, I upped the max_execution_time to 60. Seems to have solved the problem. I also sent a note to the teacher about large wiki pages. Thanks again. Peter

Post title: Wiki for case studies
Post description: I want to set up an activity on Moodle for medical case-based discussions between facilitators and students. There are likely to be about 60+ cases posted. Facilitators want to be able to put up cases for discussion in PowerPoint format.  Students will need to be able to discuss these cases as well as being able to upload their own cases. It would be good if all materials and discussions related to a particular case were kept together. So far I have tried the following: set up a discussion but the discussion activity doesn't allow uploads of PowerPoint or PDF files set up a wiki for each case. I'm concerned about the number of wikis that would need to be created. Students can upload files and start a new discussion but these are all related to that particular case. Tried to have a multiple page wiki but it didn't allow files to be attached to a particular page/case. Any suiggestions??
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Quick question - when you say "set up a discussion but the discussion doesn't allow uploads of PPT or PDF files", are you talking about forums? Forum Post: 
Post title: The problem of chinese character for OU wiki
Post description: Hi everyone, I had tested ou wiki 2.5 on moodle 1.9.10+ and found some problems. When I added new section to page or create a new page,if I typed some chinese characters as the section name or page name ,for example "校園"or "研究",after clicking the buttons "add" and "save changes",all the content is lost in this page,what's wrong? Does this module "OU wiki " agree with unicode character? Any one can give me suggestions? Thank you very much. Jing-dong wang
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I also got this in private message and replied to it, however just to clarify, my understanding (& experience here after a quick test) is that in general, OU wiki does work correctly with Chinese characters and any other unicode characters. If anybody else has insight into this, please let me know. --sam
Comment 2: Hi Sam, Thank you for your reply. I had recorded a video file of operational steps like your message. Please click this addresss and watch the attached video file. The test is on moodle 1.9.11+ with mysql ,and 2.5 ouwiki. When I had added a new section name,all of the content is blank,and no error messages are found. This phenomenon is found only for some chinese characters,like "校園" or "研究". What's wrong? Thank you for your help. Jing-Dong Wang
Comment 3: Maybe the function "str_replace" can't be used for two-byte character(chinese,japanese....). The function "mb_eregi_replace" is more proper for two-byte character. Jing-Dong Wang
Comment 4: Hi sam, I have found a solution for this problem. I have modified the function "ouwiki_format_xhtml_a_bit"  in ouwiki.php. At line 2399,the original code is $content=preg_replace('/\s+/'," ",$content); and replaced by the new code $content=preg_replace('/[\r\n\s]+/u'," ",$content); the parameter u is for multibyte character . Thank you very much for your help Jing-Dong Wang
Comment 5: Thank you. I don't understand why this solved the problem for you because this regular expression only works with ASCII characters which are not altered in UTF-8. (Also as noted, the problem doesn't occur for me including using the same strings.) However it is good that it's solved it. One possibility is that the version of the underlying 'preg' library is different on our different systems and this somehow means that it requires the /u flag on yours, but not on mine. Strange. Oh well. --sam

Forum Post: Post title: YouTube embed appears twice in a wiki Post description: I don't know if this should be reported as a bug. Here's what I just discovered after a teacher reported that an embeded (with Multimedia filter) YouTube video was displayed twice in a wiki. If you use the URL as the link text, it will be converted to a hyperlink in the wiki, causing a double link. Like this: ```text

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4uipnBkj-4

``` You must replace the text to fix it:

some texte

Using Moodle 2.6.2 Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Is it the same problem discussed in here: A tag in the forum? https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=218330 ? The solution I found is linked to the last post in that thread. Comment 2: Similar answer to the one from Visvanath Have you tried turning off the autolink filter for the wiki?  Should be doable from Administration block -> Wiki administration -> Filters Ensure you turn off the filter "Convert URLs into links and images". Otherwise, when editing the wiki page with the TinyMCE editor on, select the link and click the "No auto link" icon. Hope this helps! Comment 3: Thanks a lot for your replies. Sorry to get back so late. I just had a baby. I cannot see how to disable wiki autolinking in Moodle 2.6. There is no wiki filter and no global settings for wiki activity. François Comment 4: Hi Comment 5: I got around this by entering something other than the URL as the text of the link. In html, your href should look something like this (with "video" being variable, as long as it isn't the url of the youtube video): href="https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU">video Not like this: href="https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU"> https://youtu.be/K1hbhuUdjWU ; Label:

Comment 7: We are running Moodle 1.9.3 and this is the fix from our programmer: The tags.lib.php wiki_tags_print_editbox() method closed off the editor's form above the Save, Preview, and Cancel buttons. This made the buttons invisible to IE. There is a form close below the buttons in any case, so this is a bug in nwiki. I also fixed another bug in the wiki_tags_save_tags() method to handle the case where an argument to the method is null. If you drop in the tags.lib.php file attached above in mod/wiki/tags (replacing the one that's there) this should fix the problem with IE. Note that I'm using the latest NWiki from the developer and installed it per his instructions (that is, after removing the existing wiki in 1.9).

Forum Post: Post title: Wrong words (eg. "++") are matched as CamelCase in spite of "Disable CamelCase Linking" Post description: Hi, Moodlers. I've been in the face of two strange phenomenons under using ewiki on Moodle1.8. Under checking "Disable CamelCase Linking" on ewiki (Moodle1.8, 1.7, ...), Camel case words (eg. UsingMoodle, WikiModule...) does not match as Camel case. On the other hand, unexpected words (eg. a++, a]+[, ...) will match as Camel case. For example: for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i++)    : HTML editor ->  for ($i = 0; $i < 100; $i ++ ? )  : View page (ewiki) '++' is linked for new page. I don't expect! Another phenomenons is as following. For example: a[] is an array. a[1]   : HTML editor -> a 1 ? : View page(ewiki) : I want to avoid. a![1]  : HTML editor ->  a[1]  : View page (ewiki) : That's right. a[]   : HTML editor ->  a ? : View page(ewiki) : Oh? a![]   : HTML editor -> a![]   : View page (ewiki) : Oh No! a![ ]  : HTML editor -> a[ ]   : View page(ewiki): huum...O, OK? (How to correct these problems?) The cause of these problems is on following code, in mod/wiki/ewiki/ewiki.php if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "");
    }  else {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
    } EWIKI_CHARS_L/U are used for detecting Camel case words. These constants are used on regular-expression as follows, "wiki_link_regex" => "\007 [!~]?( \#? \[" style="border-right:0px;border-top:0px;vertical-align:middle;border-left:0px;border-bottom:0px;" alt="[^<>\[" src="http://moodle.org/filter/tex/pix.php/25443382e01c0fa744dccb716a12d8bc.gif" /> \n]+\] | \^[-".EWIKI_CHARS_U.EWIKI_CHARS_L."]{3,} | \b([\w]{3,}：)*([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,}\#?[\w\d]* | ([a-z]{2,9}://|mailto：)[^\s \[\] \'\"\)\,<]+ | \w[-_.+\w]+@(\w[-_\w]+[.])+\w{2,}   ) \007x", and $value = preg_replace_callback("/((\w+：)?([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."] +){2,}[\w\d]*)/", "ewiki_link_regex_callback", $value); Most important part is ([".EWIKI_CHARS_U."]+[".EWIKI_CHARS_L."]+){2,} . If we set that the "Disable CamelCase Linking" is On, both of EWIKI_CHARS_L and EWIKI_CHARS_U become null (blank?). Therefore, regular expression will become to ([]+[]+){2,} . [*] (eg. [A-Za-z0-9]) is meta symbol that means character class. [*] is not allowed that the inner part of brankets is null. /[]+[]+/ is interpreted as [ ]+[ ] + , then the render of ewiki view page will misinterpret non-Camel case word as Camel case word in spite of Disable CamelCase is On. /[]+[]+/ means that a word matched with the pattern consists of a character ']' or '+' or '['. I propose a modification for this problem. if ($moodle_disable_camel_case) {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "\t");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "\r");
    }  else {
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_L", "a-z_??$\337-\377");
        define("EWIKI_CHARS_U", "A-Z0-9\300-\336");
    } This patch means that CamelCase word consists of 'Carriage return' and 'Tab code', for example : '\r\t', '\r\t\r\r\t'. This experssion is safe since these strings shall not appear in plain text generally. I'm using ewiki in Japanese. After applying this modification I have no trouble under setting 'Disable CamelCase Linking'  On. If you are also in face of this problem, let's try this patch. Post description: Hi all, Because of a nasty error in the way the table of contents seems to work I want to disable the table of contents generation for a wiki page. Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Maurits, Disabling this wont help fix the error but it will hide it away. I'm not a Wiki expert, but if you go into: /mod/wiki/parser/markups/wikimarkup.php and search for protected function generate_header , then a few lines below that you have: if ($level < 4) { If you change this to: if ($level < 1) { ...the Table of Contents will disappear from ALL wikis. It should come back if you reverse the changes. Regards,  John

Post title: moodle 1.9 - Wiki Types - differnce between wiki and OUwiki
Post description: What is the difference between wiki's and ou wiki's? Pros and Cons
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Maria, we used the moodle wiki for a number of years and have been using the OU wiki since September 09. The OU wiki is much more stable / reliable after multiple edits. The old wiki generated lots of superfluous code after each edit, especially if using tables. From my experience OU wiki works best in firefox . Firefox and IE work in different ways when you use tables and the full screen editor. If you are going to write user guides you will probably need an IE version and a firefox version. In general, we are happy with our move to the OU wiki. Hope this helps. Nigel

Forum Post: 
Post title: Would a Wiki Work Best? Class and Individual Portfolios
Post description: I am teaching American History II (American History from 1865 until the Present) at a community college.  I have created a theme for the course where students apply and work at a hypothetical historical newspaper.  Each assignment relates directly to this theme, from there application to the newspaper and their vertical progression through the company.  At the end of the semester, the student will have completed a variety of assignments.  I want to create a individual portfolios and a class portfolio to track the development of this course and create a research tool for writing an article on the pedagogy of this course. Would an individual wiki work well for a individual portfolio, where an each assignment gets an individual wiki page? Could I use a group wiki for the entire class where they each post there assignment under the corresponding assignment title?  What I am thinking is that this group wiki would have several main pages, such as Applicant Cover Letter, Obituary Assignment, Internal Memo etc... Then each student would get an individual subpage.  So then there would be say 25 sub pages for each main page.  I want to organize the student work in a way that I can access easily in the future. Any advice would be much appreciated.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Bit of an old post, but for anyone's reference, we've just created a portfolio plugin that takes content from any moodle course across a site & brings in into the moodle blog . See https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=222275 for more. Chris

Forum Post: 
Post title: Create multiple wikis in one go
Post description: I would like to create a new wiki in each of several hundred courses. Apart from being attached to a different course, I would like each wiki to be identical - same name, same default first page, same description. Creating hundreds of wikis manually would be pretty painful, so I'm looking for alternatives. I thought manually editing the MySQL database might be the easiest way (generating some nice big SQL file which would create everything in one go) but it seems more complex that I'd hoped and could easily mess up the whole thing (in addition to tables mdl_wiki, mdl_wiki_entries, mdl_wiki pages and mdl_course_modules, there's a fairly obscure entry in the modinfo field in mdl_course and probably some others I haven't tracked down). I've also had a look at hacking the php code to create the wikis, but tracing through the code is proving tough (it starts with course/modedit.php?add=wiki&... but my php isn't up to tracing it all through). I'm using Moodle 1.9.2 with ewiki. Any ideas? Thanks,
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Having not had any replies on this one, and following a brief email conversation with Mike Churchward, one of the developers for the integration of ewiki and Moodle, I've concluded that this isn't easy to do and probably more involved and riskier than doing it the long, boring way. There's certainly no supported way to do it. I assume that it would be possible to script it, but from looking at the code, I've just been unable to track down the functions that actually create a new wiki, at least in a way that would let me script it.
Comment 2: Actually, I think between using the directory feature I finally got figured out and the suggestion that pigui made I think you could be on to something..... though I think that perhaps a php script that simply parsed the course IDs and created a wiki using the correct file from the correct site files directory if the course had yet to be accessed might be manageable.....
Comment 3: Hi Ian. I have an idea about how to solve your problem "easily". Have you noticed that if you delete the default "News Forum" from a course another one is created? You can hack you course formats (weeks, topics, etc ) to create a new wiki if it does not exists. You wouldn't have to deal with Moodle database and every wiki will be automatically created on user "demand" (teacher accessing to his course). Hope it helps. DFWikiLabs, Pigui.

Forum Post: 
Post title: What's the best way to make an FAQ?
Post description: I want to make an FAQ for the visitors to my moodle site that don't know much about us. Is the wiki module the best way to do this? If so, how do I make a table of contents?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Murrary One popular FAQ I have used and seen work well is the Glossary Module . It has an FAQ display type so the concept is the question and the definition is the answer. You can then have key words and categories. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa
Comment 2: Hi Murray, I think it depends on how much knowledge they're going to need. If it's just a simple idea of how it works then you could put a simple guide (or make a simple webpage) for topic 0, the heading, in your course. If it's an institution front page then there's usually space to modify the greeting (right-hand side on the standard Moodle). I've made up a couple of Word documents I link to so students can see how to operate the system (basic version) and gain better understanding of/access to e-learning (advanced version). Hope that helps, Paul

Forum Post: 
Post title: Not all groups show in drop down menu, so students can't participate
Post description: Hi guys. I had a weird problem the other day I am hoping someone can help. I set up 7 groups to partake in wikis. The groups were labeled A,B,C,D,E,F,G,. During the day students started the wiki, several students contacted me and pointed out that when they used the drop down menu to choose their group, they could only see groups A - E and that F and G were not displayed. As a teacher I could find all groups, but when I changed my role to "student" I was also unable to see the final two groups. I checked in the groups settings, the groups DO exist. Any ideas? (I am using 1.9.2) Thank you!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello We encountered the same bug, but have managed to trace it and work around it. This happens if you create a number of groups, then a wiki that is groupvisible. It seems moodle does not actually create the wiki instances until they are accessed. The work around: 1: Create everything as normal 2: Log in as teacher 3: Use the drop down menu to open each wiki (to force moodle to create the instances) This way the instances will be generated and available to all the students. I am also pretty sure that simply waiting for all students to log in and check their own wiki would solve the problem (but I have not verified this)

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Yes, that would be a neat feature ! Also when the groups are set to "Visible", not just the teacher but also the students should see each others Wikis.... Mike, what do you think about this, could you do that ?
Comment 2: If you have set up a wiki as a 'student' wiki, and you are the administrator, and the students have created their own wikis, you can view them all. When you click on it, you will see the first one (by student 'id'). In the upper right, you will see a drop-down that lets you see all the other student wikis. If no students have created one, you will get the message "You cannot create this wiki, and none have been created to view.". I've set it up intentionally so that the administrator (or teachers) cannot edit a student wiki, as this kind of violates its purpose. A group wiki, the administrator can edit. Is this what you are seeing? mike
Comment 3: Making small corrections to help the student? We are in an educational setting, not an open community. (Or another approach: When in Swiki a page is closed, it is possible to type comments in a commentbox on that page and the owner gets an automatic email.)
Comment 4: So, are you saying that, by design, I'm not supposed to be able to add anything to these pages? If so, why can't I see the pages they've created? That doesn't make any sense for any purpose. Especially since I can see them when I log on as a student in any group, I can see the pages that all groups have created. What is Swiki? I don't see any way to add comments. Can you advise me how to do this? Thanks Dick
Comment 5: Sorry, Swiki is another implementation of Wiki, I am just a demanding user of eWiki and give my comments to M&M. So my comment here is that I think teachers should have always access, because we are an educational setting not a wiki community. I use Swiki as a stand-alone program until this eWiki is fully integrated in Moodle. I like this integrated eWiki now very much: And I prefer the HTML-editor above the Wiki-simple-text-philosophy.. But this Swiki option (coomentbox) was very nice: the only thing a user had to do was place a commentbox symbol on the page, place his email in a "send me an email"" -field and lock the page. (Students can take ownership of a page when they put a lock on a individual page of a group-wiki.) A visitor sees then the locked page with the commentbox. As soon as the visitor types his comment and presses the comment-button under that box, the owner gets an email.There is no database behind it, pages are stored in XML -format. Another option I did like was the possibility for a webuser with editor rights to create a webform instead of the standard fill-in screen. The page-storing mechanism makes collecting the content of the forms to difficult, no database.. Swiki is a standalone server that runs on Mac,  Unix, Windows.. We used it for several years at our secondary schools to collect experience with collab-work on a website. Works great. http://minnow.cc.gatech.edu/swiki The program Swiki is written in the Smalltalk version Squeak. The pioneer Alan Kay is one of the founders. Their children project eToys is inspiring http://www.squeakland.org/ During meetings they play the game to install and run this Swiki-server in less then ... seconds.
Comment 6: Thank you very much for the ideas and the insight. I'll check it out.
Comment 7: By design, the 'student' wikis were for the students to enter content only, yes. I can change it, but I want to make sure that it makes sense. You should be able to see any student wiki though, so I'll try and recreate your problem. I can see any student wiki. I'll double check with groups and fix it as necessary. Other activities , such as assignments and exercises work the same way - the student enters them and the teacher looks at them. So just to be clear, the way it should work: - teachers can see any created wiki, - students can see their own wikis, teacher wikis, and group wikis (according to group rules) - teachers can edit teacher and group wikis, - students can edit their own wikis, and group wikis according to group wikis. We can modify it so that teachers could edit student wikis, but I'd appreciate some feedback on that to make sure that makes sense. Again, I'm modeling that function on the bases that a wiki is like an assignment. mike
Comment 8: Hi Mike! Why cannot another option be, teachers can see and edit any student created WIKI which addresses or is for an assignment of any sort. That would mean that teachers could see and edit Their own wikis Any student group wikis - Teacher's student groups Teacher's Assistants student groups, along with Teacher Assistant's wikis for that activity and assignment Any individual student wiki which is part of an activity (assignment) or side work in a group. I also believe that personal wikis which no one but the students, teachers, admins maintain, view and edit should be allowed, I think however they should be limited to a certain number determined by the main administrator. If it is only a few students, teachers and admins and the institution has a large amount of diskspace they may not care how many personal wikis a student may have. Of couse an administrator should have the ability to see all public wikis including any public Teacher wikis. There is one other thing however, I feel instructors/teachers and administrators should be able to have group wiks and individual wikis that administrators cannot view. Again the question of how many may come up. In essence, I feel that there should be much fexibility in how the wikis permissions should be determined with a policy sent out to other admins and to teachers as to what they are for a particular instrution so it is clear just how public their thoughts and work will be and if private personal wikis will be allowed. Probably needs a Control Panel which addresses the following, STATUS TARGETS Creation Status Main Admin, Admins, Teachers, Teaching Assistants, Students, Others (?) Type Status Individual, Groups Number Status (of each type for....) Main Admins, Admins, Teachers, Teaching Assistants, Students, Others (?). View Status Private, Public, Group, [Parents (?) - To check if student is doing assigned work - Eventually]. Edit Status Main Admins, Admins, Teachers, Teaching Assistants, Students, Others (?), I am beginning to understand wiki's more and more and see what great potential they have in a classroom. The ability to post notes as Ger has indicated and have an e-mail sent out to all involved in a group or individual wiki to notify them or the individual of a change or some type of intervention sounds really cool. If this cold be added it would be nice. Swiki however appears to need a special server to accomplish that function. Time to step back and let the MASTERS work. WP1

Comment 15: I'll look into this. You should be able to see all changes. mike
Comment 16: Alright, I double-checked the code and tested it. I was wrong; I implemented it such that teachers can edit any wiki - even student ones. So, if you're not getting that functionality, something's wrong. Now, there is an issue with changing the group mode on an existing wiki. I haven't figured out how to resolve this yet. If you were to change a group wiki, that was previously set to 'no groups' to 'separate' or 'visible', and it already had wiki entries, you would orphan that pages that were originally created. The effect you would get is that the teacher would always see the orphaned wiki first when they looked at the wiki. The teacher can see the real wikis by selecting them from the drop-down list. If the teacher edits the orphaned one, only they will see it. No students from the course would ever see the orphaned one. So, to summarize: A teacher can edit and view all wikis, regardless of type and group setting. Group wikis can be edited by anyone in the group. If the group setting is 'no groups', then anyone in the course can edit them. Group wikis can be viewed by anyone, for 'no groups' or 'visible groups', or by members of the groups for 'separate groups'. Teacher wikis can be edited by teachers only. If you are not seeing this functionality, make sure you have the latest code from CVS , and try a fresh wiki. Don't change the group setting once you have entered wiki entries. Let me know any anomalies you see. mike
Comment 17: Since the teachers can edit student wikis, they should also be able to create them for the student. I will put the code in for this today. Now, some other questions: Do we want to handle this differently for groups? Should the teacher be a member of the student's group to create the student's wiki? Should teacher editing privileges affect this? Should a teacher from a different group be able to view a student's wiki if groups is set to 'separate'? My thoughts: Editing teachers and administrators can view/change/create entries for any wiki. Non-editing teachers not assigned to a specific group can view/change/create entries for any wiki. Non-editing teachers assigned to a specific group can view/change/create entries for any wiki in their group, and view wikis in other groups for 'visible' groups. Make sense? mike
Comment 18: It makes sense, yes.
Comment 19: That's pretty consistent with what I'm wanting to do in my situation right now. I don't think the teacher should have to be a member of the group.
Comment 20: I've just checked a new version into CVS that allows teachers to create wikis for any of their students and groups according to their assigned group and edit/non-edit status. Please try it out and let me know if you see any problems. mike

Forum Post: 
Post title: Teacher can't see students' pages unless he's in a group
Post description: Hello, I have had this problem for a while, and I just want to report it here. Unless of course it's some bad configuration... When I choose group mode for a wiki, I cannot see my students' productions unless I enrol myself in a group, too. Should this be the case? I think it's confusing for teachers, they might not realize that there are any pages, thinking students had not done anything. Thank you , Ulrike
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Ulrike, I understand how this could be confusing! The group mode in Wikis often requires teachers to enroll themselves into groups to view individual student contributions within those groups. This setting is meant to simulate the group environment from the teacher's perspective but can indeed lead to misunderstandings. You might want to check the settings under Group Settings in the course admin panel. There may be an option to view all groups at once without needing to join them. If not, perhaps enabling "Separate groups" and granting teacher permissions for group-wide visibility could be a workaround. Hope this helps! Let me know if you find a different solution! BR 🤔
Comment 2: To be able to view all groups, you need to have the 'Access all groups' permission . So, that is how to control this.

Post title: problems for students editing a wiki page
Post description: hi, we are running a 1.5 moodle installation. having set up a wiki with 'html only' option and given students a page to edit with some text already on this, when students from a different location click on edit they see the raw html (including all the tags) on that page rather than how the page should be displayed. they also don't have the 'editor' icons at the top of the editing window (font, size, bold, etc) which they should have. i believe this is a problem not with the wiki as it works fine for students in other locations, but with the computers the children are running at the problem location. i know they run windows 98 but nothing more, as we teach remotely and do not have access to the school in question. anybody any suggestions for what might be causing this that we could ask the school to check and rectify? thanks

Forum Post: 
Post title: Status of Wiki modules?
Post description: Hi all, I'm sorry if I'm disturbing, but I'm a bit confused by wiki modules and diferent versions of it. I understand the standard bundled version of Wiki module is based on ErfurtWiki. While, many recent (and promissing) messages in this forum refer to "dfwiki". My conclusion was the two are not the same thing, and that there are two wiki modules being developed in parallel. Is that right? If yes, my questions would be: What is the general orientation for future bundling, which one will become standard? Which one is currently more indicated (stable, scalable, etc.) for production installations? Thank you in advance for your kind answer. Regards.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, I'm one of the developers of DFwiki. As you said, DFwiki isn't the same as ErfurtWiki. DFwiki is a completely new wiki module project. ErfurtWiki is a good software, but it doesn't work well with Moodle. Obviously, we want DFwiki to be the next Moodle oficial wiki. If you want to try it, the URL is: http://appserv.lsi.upc.es/palangana/moodle/course/view.php?id=15 I can't answer your second question (which is better) because I'm not objective. But DFwiki is developed to solve all ewiki troubles and we are working hard on it. All suggestions about DFwiki will be helpful. I recommend to try it both and post in this forum your conclusions.
Comment 2: HI John, tree months ago I asked Martin his aproval to develop a brand new wiki module. The main developer of Ewiki (current main moodle wiki) module is now missing and another moodle developer is maintanining it. In its due time Martin will have to decide if he wants dfwiki to become the official moodel wiki ( we hope so ). But before we bring this issue, dfwiki has to reach two specific requirements that martin asked: * import capability from the old ewiki. * backup / restore I believe the other requirements are allready accomplished. However, rigth now dfwiki is pretty stable, and if you want to use it within your moodle 1.5 server you only have to download , copy the files and add the activity to your courses. Cheers Ludo
Comment 3: >I believe the other requirements are allready accomplished. Is there any way to include dfwiki activity in the Moodle activity logs? The professor for the course I'm working on really likes being able to see how many times students have viewed all the other resources in Moodle (text pages, forum postings, chat logs, etc.), especially for calculating participation marks. However, under all the dfwikis, no activity is shown. Within the dfwikis themselves, I can tell which pages have been viewed the most often, but not who viewed them. Is there a setting somewhere that I can activate so that activities can be logged? If not, this would be a nice feature to have.
Comment 4: Hi again Pam, The log bug in DFwiki is already fixed in the current downloadable version (alpha 4). To install the new version only copy the content in the same directory. In the current version, DFwiki at to log a detailled information like "view", "edit", "diff"... and shows in which DFwiki has occurred and the page name where the action is made. Finally, if someone modify a page, it adds to log a "save" entry. Download the last version and don't forgot to give as fedback again, Thanks again, Ferran.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Export - MediaWiki . . . Inport - NWiki
Post description: I have tried and tested NWikis ability to export and import XML files and is seams to work flawlessly. I then got the idea to try and export some pages from a MediaWiki site (WikiBooks) to be precise, and try and import them into NWiki ... Well you can all guess ... it did not work, however, after closer inspection of the MediaWiki XML file I realized that it should be possible to write a parser that would take the MediaWiki XML tags and replace them with NWiki replacements. There are many tags in the NWiki XML file that are LMS dependent, these are what makes NWiki more suited to our educational needs. I am guessing that if there is no corresponding tag in the MediaWiki file then they can be simply inserted with defaults. I am imagining a stand alone parser at the moment but I'm sure that this could be written into the php scripts that read in the XML files and it could be implemented transparently in NWiki. What do the rest of you wiki'ers think? Linds

Comment 2: Yes, exactly. I guess it wasn't a bug, then. It was intended to be like that. At any rate, I think it is better if the teacher can choose the default editor. The students can always choose to change it later on if they want. But this way you can avoid confusions like the ones my students have. Think that Moodle is used in all kinds of environments: even in primary schools. So the possibility to maintain a familiar environment is always desirable in some contexts. The teacher can judge whether with his or her group of students the dfwiki editor is more desirable as the default editor. Josep M.
Comment 3: Hi Ludo: Thanks for all that you and your team are doing with dfwiki. The words "Change to one of the following editors" tells the new user to change to an editor other than the default editor.  As this works now, the choice cannot be changed once selected. In order to avoid this confusion, the teacher should be able to make the default editor the only choice. In the meantime, the option "Change to one of the following editors" could be moved down below the buttons: save, preview, cancel. That way new users will be more likely to use the default editor and not lock themselves into one of the other options. Again thanks for all that you are doing, John
Comment 4: I agree. I would REALLY like to be able to force my students to use a particular editor. In my case I want to force the dfwiki editor rather than allowing users to choose the HTML editor. One of the key things about a wiki is that the markup is simple so that you are encouraged to concentrate on content rather than spending time of pretty colours and presentation . May be what is needed is a check box in the wiki settings next to "preferred editor" which says "Force preferred editor"? Or will this just overload the settings page with more options? --Stuart.
Comment 5: I agree completely with both of you. We need an option to make a markup mandatory. We will need to find a place in the options form will. cheers Ludo ps. I've translated this request to the http://docs.moodle.org/en/NWiki_roadmap

Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki Picture Problems!!! Help please
Post description: Hello, Long time reader first time poster... My students are having trouble with pictures in the wiki assignment in moodle 1.9 They are working on make a wiki entry and they have to write a few paragraphs and then add some photos. The problems are: 1. Some students can just drag and drop and it works some don't work for what ever reason.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hello.  We are running 1.9.2+ and have used wiki's extensively: www.henrycort.org/hccc I always instruct users to use the upload file method of image insertion.  Copy and paste does not copy the image source, just the link to the source; so for example if the source was on a user's computer hard drive then the image would only be visible when the path to the source was valid i.e. when the wiki was viewed from that particular pc.
Comment 2: Thanks for getting back to me. The only problem with that is that students will not have access to the file upload method due to how moodle does not allow students to have file folders. There is no place for the students to upload
Comment 3: One workaround to resize pictures is to edit them in GIMP to the size you want. Clumsy but it works. The uploading pictures is more difficult to workaround - you could them give them editing facilities in a course designed to store the images and then they can link to the image in that course.
Comment 4: For different reasons I have created a role of scholar - an 'editingteacher' at course level. I have given a small group of students this role in one course, to give them their own space for creative writing - this has worked well. It would be simple I think to refine the role to suit your needs.
Comment 5: On your settings page set allow binary files to yes. This enables the attachments tab Students can the tab to upload files, which can be either an attachment to a page or displayed on the page by inserting a link on the page i.e. [internal://image_name.jpg]
Comment 6: Sir, can you please tell me how can i resize the image. I have tried [internal://image.jpg | 100px] but it didnt work for me.

Post title: sticky login for fictional student
Post description: Hi, I am using Moodle 1.5.2 with a Windows XP Pro client and Internet Explorer and Mozilla Firebird . In order to test a new separate group course, I am logging in under multiple user accounts, my teacher (I am also admin) account plus several fictional student accounts -- made-up names with real yet unique email accounts. I have tried this using both single instances of IE , and multiple instances, each with unique account. One of my wiki resources is set up so the teacher can read/write, students read-only. I find it a great place to create teacher "space" for structured resources. When I log in as a fictional student, I can read wiki entrys. If I attempt to edit them as the fictional student, the edit tab disappears, as expected, I think. When I log out as the fictional student, and log in as me again, the teacher, I cannot edit any wiki entries that were tested by the fictional student -- the student is shown as still logged in for the pages in question. However, I am showed as logged in for other wiki pages untouched by the student. I am using Internet Explorer on the same computer for each session. I closed all instances of IE, and tried again. No luck, the student is still logged in. I repeated the experiment with Mozilla Firebird and was successful -- the student was not logged in. However, when I again repeated the test with IE, the student was still logged in. I restarted my computer, suspecting something "sticky" with IE, but restarting did not solve the problem, the student was still logged in. Does anyone know what is happening here? How do I clear the "sticky" student login? -Ron

Post title: Uploaded pictures not saving consistantly in Wiki
Post description: I am having issues with Moodle 2.6 and Wikis. Uploaded images are just not consistently sticking. Students insert an image (images) in the page of their Wiki. They show up fine at first. Student saves the page and all seems fine. However, when they return a day or so later to their page, their picture is no longer there. Students are blaming each other for deleting their pictures. Using a Wiki has been a complete disaster as the reason for using a wiki is to foster collaboration. Instead, I have several angry students and parents. After viewing the Wiki forum it seems this is an issue that is affecting more than just me. Has there been any resolution to this issue? I really want to continue using Wikis, but if there is no resolution, my principal wants them to be removed from the class. I have looked at two or three Moodle trackers, but they all seem to get closed since the issue cannot be reproduced. I'm not sure if I should open up a new one or not. Fingers crossed someone out there can let me know what I can do to resolve this. Thanks!!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Same here! Yes, please do start a new Tracker issue, I have excellent descriptions of the problem to add, and I was contemplating the same thing. We're running 2.6.2 and we've had this problem for over a year: the reports last fall that cmoore added were us, too. It's difficult to reproduce because it happens when there is a class all working in a wiki at the same time, but not when only one or two people are editing a wiki. This means it _looks_ fine when one or two staff test it out, but when students are getting close to deadlines they have their image links break and freak out and come banging on our doors. We're considering testing out OU Wiki as an alternative but we would far rather use the regular wiki if this bug can be chased down. Here's a roundup of the relevant links for the infamous draftfile.php bug . https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=170655 https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=185839 And this Moodle Tracker issue: https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-26782 ...on which you'll see us reporting the problem last fall around this time. We don't think it was ever fixed in 2.4. We're certainly still having it. John, please do open up a new tracker issue, I'll both add to it and encourage others who have had the problem to speak up. It's a leading source of frustration about our install right now, and we have faculty with a long history of wiki projects under our previous CMS and we need to find them a solution that behaves at deadline time. Thanks!

Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: James - we do something similar by using the Restrict access settings and also using the site homepage for the content (smart). Our domains for teachers email address is different from our student email. Therefore we restrict access by profile > using the teacher email domain to only have access and be visible. Now if you use a single wiki with content for teachers and students this will not work. You would need 2 separate wikis.

Comment 5: That should do it. Thanks again.

Forum Post: 
Post title: CamelCase Links
Post description: I don't seem to be able to make CamelCase work in a Wiki. Can you help me?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Me neither....would love to know too please!!!
Comment 2: Hello Cherry Hey, I found out quite by accident, that the way to make the links in your wiki work is to turn off CamelCase in the setup of the wiki, then just use square brackets around the item you want to be a link in the edit box, save it, and voila! You will see the blue question mark next to your desired link. When you click on that blue question mark in the view mode, it will take you to the page for that link. Once you name the linked page, your link is established. Hope this makes sense. Mike

Forum Post: 
Post title: How can I upload an exel file?
Post description: Hi, I would like our students to access an excel document from the main
page of our course. I have not been able to make accessible from moodle. How can I upload it so it shows in the course window so that students can edit it? Thank you for any advice. Sarah
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Sarah, This is straightforward and you don't need to create a wiki if you're looking for students to access the file as is from the course outline. To do this you should 'display a directory'. Here's how: Go to the Files area of your course (in Administration block) Create a new directory. It doesn't matter what it's called, but you might want to call it 'excel documents' click on it to enter the directory. Now you want to browse and upload the Excel document that you want to make available. Having done this, return to the main course outline and make sure that Editing is switched on. Find the weekly or topic block that you want to present the file in and choose Add a resource -> Display a directory Give the resource a name, perhaps, 'Excel files' and in the summary say what kind of spreadsheets are going here. Pull down Display a directory and choose the 'Excel documents' directory. Click Save changes. Now the contents of this directory will be displayed to your students when they click the resource link.

Forum Post: 
Post title: What is Wiki and what can I do with it?
Post description: I keep seeing alot about Wiki on here and I have no idea what it is.  So, what is WIKI and what can I do with it?  I'm a new Moodle admin, so i'm learning as I go. thanks
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Check this link out for one of the first wikis. Essentially, a wiki is a way for everyone to add content to a web page. They can create new pages, edit existing ones and see a change history of all of them. We use it to add an activity to a course that allows multiple participants to create and edit web pages. This implementation lets you specify who is allowed to edit and who can only view. Additionally you can multiple parallel wiki structures being maintained by different people / groups. mike

Post title: True Newbie wonders how to get DFWiki into her Moodle
Post description: Hi, I'm just setting up my first Moodle on the space I recently purchased at BlueHost.com.  I know next to nothing about Apache Servers, PHP and the other good things that make Moodle do what it does.  Moodle installed just fine since the site has Fantastico . Now I'm looking at the delights of DFWiki and wishing I had it to use on my Moodle.  I've been poking around in the documentation but don't understand the basics of what I will need to do.  I assume I will download the DFWiki module. FTP it to my site.  Expand it on my site, and then...?  How do I get it into Moodle? Everything associated with Moodle seems to be so well documented that I'm certain this is documents some where, I just haven't found it. Thanks in advance for any assistance you can give.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: HI Susan, the dfwiki zip file contains the files and directories that you have to copy into your moodle main directory (the mod, lang, and blocks directory, I think). Then you have to enter in your moodle app as admin user and then the module will execute its update sscrits. Just remember that right now dfwiki does not yet support postgresql , so you should be using mysql . Now you just have to add dfwiki activities or dfwiki courses. I recomend you use the last version, we released two days ago, is proiving to be pretty stable. Cheers and wellcome to moodle. Marc
Comment 2: Are there any step by step instructions for this anywhere? I'm struggling with follwoing exactly where to put which directory or what has to be done as an admin. To use dfwiki seems like the way forward but without *clear* (and i mean DLEAR, numbered, step by step without assuming anything) documentation of installation it just seems a little too difificult - I'm going to try piecing together the scant instructions to date and seeing what happens, and maybe documenting it. Any help appreciated!
Comment 3: Hi steve... the dfwiki zipfile comes with 3 directories ( sometimes within a main directory called dfwiki_1.0_rev2006xxxx ...) mod lang and course you must copy this directories inside the main moodle installation dir. Then you have to enter into the "admin"  page of moodle logged as an admin user . Then dfwiki will start updating the database , as allways you install a new module. Then you can add a "dfwiki" activities in you courses. Feel free to use the dfwiki blocks by turning editing mode on... as when you play with your moodle courses... Regards Marc
Comment 4: Hi Susan, I've been getting a little lost on this too - have succesfully installed dfwiki and tried to create a simple step-by-step to doing this here I think we're both looking for something like this http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:Contents#For_readers which is for mediawiki, or a similar level of documentation to that in the moodle manuals. I think we'll need to create this ourselves - Ludo's been a great help (thnaks) but there seems to be a lack of the kind of guide we're both looking for - what each block does, how to start etc. I like what i see of dfwiki but find it complex to use - also wonder what the issues are with visiblke groups or not.. (old bug for moodle wiki module)
Comment 5: Hello steve, I tried to follow your instructions, and I was able to copy and paste all the folders to my moodle dir, but when I tried to gain access to my admin page the mod will update my database and everything, but at the last minute it will get stuck saying it needs to update the database with dfwiki, I keep clicking to go back to the page or even go back to the main page of the site and it will keep taking me to the admin section to update database for dfwiki, (no errors) any suggestions in what might be the problem with the install... Forum Post: 
Post title: Wiki and Copyright
Post description: If one has a closed course that contains a wiki, is it legally enforcable to restrict students from sharing the content of that wiki beyond the course if it is stated up front that copyright of the material remains with the organization offering the course, with the exception that individual students retain the copyright of the material they themselves compose personally in the wiki?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I am not a lawyer but... The organization can enforce the copyright of its material, but cannot automatically act on behalf of the other students to enforce the copyright of the material they have created, as they retain this. You create the wiki Student A adds some content Student B copies A's content to a public arena You have no IP redress against student B, but student A does , as you've said that student A retains the copyright of the material they composed, which they would have done anyhow, unless they'd agreed otherwise. You might however want to phrase the AUP in such a way that you can expel student B from the course. It might be worth using a creative commons licence for the wiki stuff, as it would be difficult to identify who has composed the material, and thus retains the copyright, if it goes through a process of iterative editing.
Comment 2: I like the point that what a student writes belongs to them. My concern is not if a little bit of it slips out at the hands of the individual authors, it is the whole work that would be a problem. But since each individual owns their own copyright, they would have to work en masse to do that.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Is wiki the best way to approach this problem?
Post description: I am trying to implement MOODLE as a support and training site for my company. On the support side, I had been using PHPBB as a place to enter and store hints and fixes we have found for the various systems problems. So right now I have a phpbb forum for the phone system, and entry for the voice mail system, software, and so on. what I would like is a place were anyone can record the steps the have found that will fix a particular problem and have a place were others can add to the solution if they find something else that works. I tried using the BOOK module, but that is too restrictive in that others don't seem to be able to add to it. I have played with the wiki module thinking that would allow others to add to the entry but it looks like i would need separate wikis for each system, that is on for the phones, one for the voice mail, one for the hardware and so on. Am I correct in my thinking here? I have also looked at using the forum module in the same manner as I did with the PHPBB installation. Here again I seemed to run into issues in that when created on the main page, it seems only the admin is able to edit or add to the forum. Perhaps my problem is in my understanding of how MOODLE works and in how I have it set up. Any suggestions would be greatly appreciated. Regards Rick
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I would say one wiki would be enough, with separate pages for each issue. The front page should be the 'forum overview', with links to each issue. The problem with wiki as forum is that it is mainly a tool for collaborative writing, so it allows several users to write on the same pages. This is also one of the problems you see e.g. on wikipedia, where several authors write on each page, and thus creates a kind of discussion that can be very unstructured, commenting in between each other etc. Forums do not allow other users to change what another user has written. So for a wiki to be successful as forum tool, there has to be some guidelines easy enough for all to understand, and some moderators to ensure compliance. If you create separate wikis - this might make it easier for the users to handle different issues - you should add links on the pages between the wikis so it is easy to navigate between them. But it is important to design the forums/wikis with the users, to see how it best suits them Forums in moodle can be used the same way as forums in phpBB, depends on the settings. It looks like your forum is restricted who can reply - but this is not your fault, the standard news forum is normally for one way communication. Moodle forums have two settings that control who is allowed to post and reply, check them out. And one great thing with Moodle forums is that your users can subscribe to them to receive postings with email or via RSS feeds. So forum or wiki? I think it depends on how much effort you want to use to structure the communication. The forum tool is more focused, the wiki is more open. But to me it sounds like you would be best helped with the forum. /Ian
Comment 2: Ian: Thanks for your comments,I played with the forum idea some more and I think I have come to the conclusion that what I really need for this function is PHPBB. I found that I could like to my existing PHPBB site using the "add resources". I need the different levels of category and topics that php gives me and linking doesn't create that much of an issue with my users. I will continue to play with this package though since I need to create employee evaluation tests with it. Thanks Again Rick
Comment 3: You could add the glosary module to the list of possibilities. In brief, Forum : everibody could post. Anibody could edit THEIR posts but only during the next 30'. Nobody could edit the post of others (they could add new post as reply). Glosary : everibody could post. Anibody could edit THEIR posts allways. Nobody could edit the post of others (they could add commnets or new entries) Wiki : everybody and everytime could post and edit what they or others write.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Simultaneous editing occurs in wiki with overwriting of data as result
Post description: Hi all, We have discovered that the edit protection in the wiki of Moodle 2 is not watertight. Normally, if a (student) user tries to edit a (collaborative) wiki page that is being edited by another user, they would see an error message: " Someone is editing this page right now. Try to edit it in a few minutes. " However, experience has shown that nonetheless it is sometime possible for users to edit a wiki page simultaneously with as a result that the data of the user who saves first is overwritten by the one who saves last. Our tests have so far identified three possible scenarios: An interruption in the Internet connection. If a user, for instance using an unstable wireless connection, suffers a short interruption in his connection, another user can open the editing mode of the same page, provided they click at the right moment. A mix up with open browser windows or tabs If a user leaves the wiki in editing mode in one browser tab then opens another with which he/she also surfs to the wiki and then gets the view mode, another user can open editing mode for the same page even though the first user still has it open. Using the back button If a user edits and saves a wiki page, the pages becomes editable by another user, but the first user can use the back button of his/her browser to reurn to editing mode without encountering the error message. We wonder if anyone else has noticed these and other cases where the edit protection fails? And also if anyone has suggestions for improvements, apart from instructions to students for proper use of the tool. We use Moodle 2.3.2+ Rgrds, Paul.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Unable to upload files to Wiki: [[uplrejsect]] error
Post description: Hello, Since updating my Moodle system via CVS last Monday (the 24th September) I and students have been able unable to upload files to Wikis - the default Wiki that comes with Moodle, not NWiki, DFWikii etc. When trying to the upload a file via the upload dialogue box below the HTML editor a new tab opens, but with no information about the file I wanted to upload. Normally, a text would appear which I'd copy into the editor to create a link to that uploaded file. When I try to upload a file via the attachments tab I get a the following 'error message' in the attachments page: uplrejsect This happens with all browsers and file types. This has been reported before: click to see previous related messages .
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Just to confirm that we are also getting this error. Amanda
Comment 2: Hello Amanda and anyone else trying to use the default Wiki, In the absence of a solution to this bug (files can't be uploaded) I have come up with a workaround. Using the Database activity module I have created an 'activity' called 'File Bank'. Students upload their files to that, and then copy the URL for the file that they want to add or link to their Wiki. Students then access their Wiki and use the icons in the HTML editor to either add links to files in the 'File Bank', or embed images that have been saved in the 'File Bank'. This seems to work better than the original method of adding attachments to wiki pages. Hope this idea is of use to other moodlers.
Comment 3: Hi, we had the same problem here at our end, but I concluded that I have to hack the code myself to get it to work. Now, the problem was in the file moodle_binary_store.php, which can be found within the directory /mod/ewiki/plugins/moodle/ The problem was that the save path and location for the file to be saved was created from the wiki name . I changed this to the following in the function moodle_binary_store_file: function moodle_binary_store_file(&$filename, &$id, &$meta, $ext=".bin") { # READ-Only global $_FILES, $CFG, $course, $wiki, $groupid, $userid, $ewiki_title, $cm; if(!$wiki->ewikiacceptbinary) { error("This wiki does not accept binaries"); return 0; } $entry=wiki_get_entry($wiki, $course, $userid, $groupid); if(!$entry->id) { error("Cannot get entry."); } require_once($CFG-> dirroot .'/lib/uploadlib.php'); $um = new upload_manager('upload',false,false,$course,false,0,true,true); if ( $um->process_file_uploads("$course->id/$CFG->moddata/wiki/$wiki->id/$entry->id/")) { $filename = ''; // this to make sure we don't keep processing in the parent function if(!$id) { $newfilename = $um->get_new_filename(); $id = EWIKI_IDF_INTERNAL.$newfilename; } return true; } error($um->print_upload_log(true)); return false; } I also changed this in the function moodle_binary_get_path: function moodle_binary_get_path($id, $meta, $course, $wiki, $userid, $groupid) { global $CFG,$ewiki_title; $entry=wiki_get_entry($wiki, $course, $userid, $groupid); if(!$entry) { error("Cannot get entry."); } $dir=make_upload_directory("$course->id/$CFG->moddata/wiki/$wiki->id/$entry->id/"); return "$dir"; } So, now it reflects the wiki->id and entry->id instead. It now works for us. Hope it will help somebody else to!

Forum Post: 
Post title: the "code" tag seems to be not activated
Post description: hello, i'm working with the moodle wiki here on moodle.org and on my installation. paralell i work with some ewiki installations in another context . ewiki supports the "code" tag to be able to integrate code snippets in wiki pages. i noticed that the "code" tag is not interpreted in the moodle wiki. ewiki changes 'code' to 'pre class="markup code"', the moodle wiki lets it unchanged. in the ewiki documentation the difference between 'pre' and 'code' is described as follows: 
```text
#  use the 'pre' ... '/pre' 'tags' for a paragraph of 
preformatted text, that still allowed to use WikiWords and 
simple markup

# with 'code' ... '/code' instead you would really see text as 
you typed it, with square brackets and other escapes not 
garbaging your text
```

Forum Post: 
Post title: Headers sent Error for newbie to Wiki
Post description: I'm new to moodle and just tried my first wiki The wiki term was explained in my local newspaper so I felt I was behind the times and should give it a try. Sorry if this is a common error. I wanted to post it in case it helps anyone debug later. When you try to use this activity you get an error: Warning: is_executable(): open_basedir restriction in effect. File(/usr/bin/patch) is not within the allowed path(s): (/usr/local/psa/home/vhosts/roweclassroom.com/httpdocs:/tmp) in /usr/local/psa/home/vhosts/roweclassroom.com/httpdocs/courses/mod/wiki/ewiki/plugins/patchsaving.php on line 15 Headers sent
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I've never seen this before. Nor am I sure what it is... What version of Moodle are you running?
Comment 2: Same problem for me and I don't find the solution. I use moodle 1.4.3 thanxs for answers
Comment 3: I get the same error with one web host , but no error with
another.  I am using 1.4.4+.  I can create a wiki on the bad
site if I remark out lines 12 and 13 of the patchsaving.php file, but
it does not function properly.  I have a local test machine that
works fine as well.  It seems to be just the one web host. 
The url is http://robjohnson.org/moodle/ .  Any help would be appreciated. Rob
Comment 4: The problem are the same with 1.5.2 on one of my server (free.fr), but no problem on my local server (easyphp 1.8) I remark lines 12 and 13 like Rob, and the wiki seems to be ok.
Comment 5: Still having problems with this? As it says in the error message, you are not allowed to execute /usr/bin/patch, because your service provider uses open_basedir restriction. The function is_executable returns false, and the plugin 'edit_patch' does not get loaded. This is the correct behaviour, I believe. Have you enabled 'debug' mode in your Moodle (configuration/variables/debug). If not, the warning should not appear and mess with your headers. If debug has been set to 'No' and you still get the warning, you can remove it by adding an error control operator (@): 
```text
  if (@is_executable( ...
```
 Regards, Jarkko.

Forum Post: 
Post title: links to smb: url in wiki
Post description: Didn't see this topic addressed anywhere, so apologies if it's been dealt with. I'm trying to add links that refer to files on an SMB share, something like smb:// server /share/path/filename doing what came naturally, (leftbracket) title (vertical bar) smb://server/share/path/filename (rightbracket) Didn't recognize the URL type. I'm using ewiki now, but I presume this would be addressed by dfwiki as well. Hm.  Investigating this with Firefox on windows & linux, and the smb://  syntax didn't seem to be recognized , although it is with IE on Windows and appears to work on the Macintosh.  Perhaps there's a standardized way of accessing smb shares through a browser of which I'm not aware?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: HI, the dfwiki parser automatically creates a link for the web adresses (starting with http ) we did'nt consider the smb protocol as one to be parsed. A solution to your porblem would be to use html editor pages and create there the links directly. With dfwiki you can choose wich markup languages (dfwiki ewiki htmleditor )  when you create the page. Regards Ludo
Comment 2: Thanks.  I'll probably work around it by making a local smb file mount. Apparently web browsers differ in how they handle the smb:// protocol.
Comment 3: Linking to local files is widely considered to be a security hazard so the browsers are all dropping it. Pity.
