Post title: Image link not transferring
Post description: I have an html page that is set to use as the source page for a wiki. The html page is stored in the files section of our site and is fully intact. However, when I select that page as an initial source page for our wiki, the text shows up just fine but the image on the page does not show up. It seems like maybe there is some kind of path naming problem, but I can't figure it out. Any ideas...? Thanks, Whitney
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Do you have CamelCase linking enabled, and does the name of the file contain mixed case characters. I discovered this morning that if I uploaded a file called "MyPicture.jpg" to the wiki with CamelCasing enabled, Moodle would dutifully link the file name, which appears to have the effect of removing the source information from the image. The end result is that the image would show up in preview (which apparently doesn't try and CamelCase the images), but not in the wiki. When I disabled CamelCase linking, the image displayed properly. Ken Newquist Lafayette College
Comment 2: Ken: Thanks, I tried that and to no avail. The image file was all lower case anyway. Whitney

Forum Post: 
Post title: How to transfer Wiki with content between courses?
Post description: I want to copy a wiki to a different course. I tried with backup and restore, yet the restored wiki was completely empty except the description text field. Is this a bug or a feature?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Martin, I guess that's a feature. Same will happen with a Forum, Glossary or Database activity. This has to do with the fact that the content in these activities is generally created by your participants, making this 'user data'. If you backup/restored the activity or course without the enrolled users, the user data will not be incorporated in the backup file. You can, though, anonymize the user data, and then create the backup file as a workaround.

Forum Post: 
Post title: Standard version 2 Wiki doesn't seem to understand groups and groupings
Post description: Hello, Is anyone else having problems with groups and the standard Wiki module in Moodle version 2? I'd like to be able to set up a wiki on a version 2 moodle system in which, "there is one wiki per group, students can change the wiki of their own group only, and they can view the wikis for all groups." When using moodle 1.9 and the standard issue Wiki I often set up a wiki so that small groups of students could collaboratively edit their own group wiki, and view the wikis of other groups (see the yellow cell in the table below). This does not seem to be possible in version 2. Either students are able to edit both their own group's and other groups' wikis, OR they can only edit their own group's wiki and not even see other groups' wikis. The settings for a 1.9 wiki to make this group collaboration possible were (also see yellow cell in the table below): Type: groups Group mode: visible Grouping : Grouping-A (this setting not necessary, but useful in courses with lots of groups) The Wiki settings in version 2 are different. These settings; Wiki mode: Collaborative Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A result in a wiki in which students can edit their own group's wiki AND those of other groups. I was hoping that these settings would emulate the 1.9 version described above (and in the yellow cell below). These settings: Wiki mode: Individual Group mode: Visible groups Grouping: Grouping-A Available for group members only: checked result in a wiki in which students cannot edit a group wiki (to be expected) but can edit their own wiki. They can also see the wikis of other students. The strange thing about these settings is that even with the "Available for group members only" checked, students can see a menu of all students and groups in the course, not just the groups in the relevant grouping. I have tried other combinations of settings, but none get the result I want and used to be able to get in 1.9. i.e. "one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups". This is a bug, surely? For your reference, here are the Wiki types available in 1.9, copied from the help files of a 1.9 system: Wiki types (in 1.9) There are three wiki types: Teacher, Groups, Student. In addition, like any activity, the wiki has the Moodle group modes: "No Groups" "Separate Groups" and "Visible Groups". This leads to the following matrix of nine possibilities: No Groups Separate Groups Visible Groups Teacher There is only one wiki which only the teacher can edit. Students can view the contents. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wiki of their group only. There is one wiki for every group which just the teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis for all groups. Groups There is only one wiki. The teacher and all students can view and edit this wiki. There is one wiki per group. Students can view and edit the wiki of their own group only. There is one wiki per group. Students can change the wiki of their own group only. They can view the wikis for all groups. Student Every student has their own wiki which only they and their teacher can view and edit. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of other students in their group. Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can edit. Students can view the wikis of all other students in the course. Unless the group mode has been forced by the course settings, it can be set with the groups icons on the course home page after the wiki has been created. So how can this group wiki feature be emulated in version 2? _______________________ Environment: Moodle 2.0.2+ (Build: 20110413) php 5.3.3 MySQL 5.5.9
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I agree, this is no good! The possibility to choose that groups can read and also comment on each others group-wiki would be fine, but they should not be able to "cross-edit".
Comment 2: Peter, Thanks for your comment. This issue has been reported as a bug: MDL-27037 I do hope that this serious flaw in the Wiki module can be fixed soon. Until then, it renders this module pretty much unusable in any course that requires groups to co-edit their group's wiki, and just view those of other groups.
Comment 3: thanks for reporting it, we will look into it...
I cannot give an answer yet, wiki modes are tricky...
We will report on the tracker issue.
Comment 4: Ludo, Thanks for your reply and for looking into this bug. " I cannot give an answer yet, wiki modes are tricky... " The thing is, many of the users of the standard Wiki in Moodle 1.9 got used to the concept of groups being able to edit their own wiki but not those of other groups. It is not easy to explain to people that a core feature of the Wiki (and of Moodle given it's constructivist foundations) no longer exists in the new Moodle version.
Comment 5: Was this issue sorted?
Comment 6: I tried the wiki out on the 2.2 beta and still had navigation problems using 'visible groups'. We've resorted to using a clunky workaround for existing courses that use it. You can see that in this thread here - http://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=190581#p832518 There's a tracker entry here: http://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-30478

Post description: Well, the wiki module is listed as possibly being replaced by OU Wiki at some point in the future in the Roadmap . The question I would ask here is why was this not done in the transition from v1.9 to v2.0? I know I am being unfair, the amount of excellent work done by a lot of people, (none by me), should not be so casually dismissed, but as a fan of wikis, I am actually appalled that the Moodle wiki is so.. so... dowdy.  It was poor in v1.9, and did not fare any better in v 2.0. I understand there was a substantial debate around a new wiki for v2 but really, the end result is disappointing. I know the perception has always been that MoodleWikis should be course specific, but I would ask why? This may have been desireable a few years ago, but is it still so? For me, Moodle wikis can work at two levels, one is site wide, much the same as Forums and Docs do here, (but with a single login). The other is at a course level. Most educational institutions, and businesses for that matter, could well use a tool with that kind of flexibility. Wikis can be specific, and general, and as a place for all sorts of information. We are now well used to using Wikipedia as a source, but what if a school, for example, had the opportunity to develop a school wide Moodlewiki? What if a class of students had the ability to develop a single wiki for an ancient History class, and their teacher could use that as a fully annotated and referenced demonstration of student learning. Better still, could the teacher then not allow continued development of that wiki at a site level?  Over time, it could become an incredibly valuable resource for a school. Is this not what wikis should be? Rather than OU Wiki, why not use MediaWiki as Moodle Docs does? Why not fully integrate MediaWiki as a part of Moodle. Any comments or suggestions are most welcome.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I agree, I'd like to have wiki content that can persist beyond a student's course enrollment. We also see a value in being able to selectively publish some content for public viewing (i.e. viewing by users not enrolled in our institution).
Comment 2: That is not a use that I had actually thought about Elizabeth, but is a great suggestion. That would be a very useful tool in a lot of different contexts. Thank you.
Comment 3: It would be great to have stronger MediaWiki integration with Moodle. My  team uses both extensively. There are some education-focused extensions and initiatives related to MediaWiki, but nothing even close to Moodle. The current wiki plugins for Moodle are far to limiting.
Comment 4: I agree Nathan, the current wiki module is far too limiting. The idea of Moodle is flexibility, and there is, of course, strong argument that Wikis should relate to courses, as activities , but the broader picture is overlooked in that context . Flexibility should not always mean just within Moodle. The other important thing too is that there needs to be a single login policy. That does not happen in Moodle.org, and I do not understand why? It is likely if there is a embedding of mediaWiki into Moodle that the login process will be taken care of. Currently, in our circumstance, our students log into their computers/network, then to the internet, then to Moodle, then to a wiki (if we had one). Now, to me that is just putting barriers in place. (I know that there is a couple of programs that will change this, like iChain, but that assumes all network techs have a high skill set and that is not always the case.)
Comment 5: The content of this forum post has been removed and can no longer be accessed.
Comment 6: I would LOVE the ou wiki as standard ASAP!!! We used it exclusively & extensively as our wiki from 1.9 to 2.2 & I miss is a lot!!  The ability to create a template & the ease of use were the real bonuses. The current wiki just doesn't compare.

Post title: I can't see my students' wikis
Post description: I created wikis for my students today to create revision pages for their most recent topic.  I created groups of 2-3 students and then created groupings for each individual group (as far as I could see, this was the best method to theoretically allow them to only edit their group's wiki).  They were working on them in class and were told to finish them for homework. When I went to check them this evening, I clicked on their wikis and the editing page came up with only the description that I had assigned when setting up the wikis. I have tried changing settings, adding teachers to the grouping , adding myself to their groups.  I can see that they have been working on them when I check the activity logs, but I can't see what they've done. Desperate to resolve this issue asap. Thanks in advance!
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi Deirdre, This looks like this is a bug that has been fixed for versions 2.2.7 , 2.3.4 and 2.4.1! It appears to be connected with setting groups and also the 'forced format', say HTML format, at the same time. MDL-35653 applies I believe. You could just try UNTICKING the 'force format' box and see if things return to normal, HOWEVER, I wouldn't alter ANY settings on ANY module that already contained student work without first using Backup in the Course Administration and backing-up everthing - especially WITH all the User data settings ticked (on some sites this requires an administrator!). I offer this caution because on some modules changing settings may reset the activity data. So this is either good practice or total paranoia! Regards, John

Post title: Wiki Wondering....
Post description: How does a Wiki work as a class project? I have little knowledge in what they do, other than looking up information. Apparently, I can go into the Moodle Wiki, for example, and suggest a correction or to enter new information but that is about the extent of my understanding.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Moving to Wiki forum...
Comment 2: Well, it is basically like Wikipedia - a place where students can edit a document collaboratively and where each edit/deletion and addition is recorded with the person's name and time.
Comment 3: Yes, the link is a good start. We are presently in 3.1 and I presume that it will carry over to 3.5 later this month. Thank you.
Comment 4: When you work with a collaborative wiki in Moodle you have to consider a few things: What is the content you want to add in your wiki? In case you want to use some advanced features like some embeded activites, you will need to write a filter to do so. For instance, you can't embed H5P activities without a filter. How many people will edit the wiki at the same time. With the Moodle wiki only one person can edit a certain page at the same time. When working with students - who sometimes forget to save their work, this might cause problems, as other students will not be able to edit the same page. Choose the name of the main wiki page carefully, as you can't change it afterwards.
Comment 5: What is the content you want to add in your wiki? I am figuring that this one will be an experiment.  The editing will be done by any student that wants to edit.  The object is for students to do research, or apply their own knowledge, and explain how Twitter works. How many people will edit the wiki at the same time. With
the Moodle wiki only one person can edit a certain page at the same
time. When working with students - who sometimes forget to save their
work, this might cause problems, as other students will not be able to
edit the same page. Good point, Students will be warned.  I think the odds of a collision here will be reduced because they will not be editing during class.  It will be homework.  I will stongly suggest that they write the edit in a document before they copy it to the wiki. Choose the name of the main wiki page carefully, as you can't change it afterwards. Yes, I saw that.  Right now, I have a few test models to check things.  I will leave one so students can check their wiki skills.
Comment 6: Could you post a screen shot of a sample document and another one showing how you edit it?
Comment 7: Are you asking how to edit a wiki in general or how I plan to do editing in class? If you are new to Wiki then there is a good video in MoodleDocs .  The easiest way to get started if to go directly to https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/Wiki_activity . Play the video a few times then we can help you understand it. If you are asking me what I plan to do, well, that has not been established yet.  For this first round, I am going to open it up to all students and see what happens.  I will get more into it in a few days or a week or so.  I can let you know when I figure it out. ( :
Comment 8: No. I am asking, in your opinion, how a good tool, wiki or any other thing, looks like. Anyway, this discussion is stale. There is another "Wiki Wondering" in the General help forum: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=372590 .

Post title: Individual wiki where students can view one another's
Post description: Hello I have done extensive research and testing, but I can't seem to figure this out.  I would like to create a wiki where each student in the course has his own set of pages within the wiki, and where each student can see the other students' wikis.  My research has resulted in conflicting facts.  This page essentially makes it seem like it's not possible to do this.  However, I've found other posts ( here and here ) that indicate that indicate that if I create it as an individual wiki, and set the group mode to "Visible Groups" then: " Every student has their own wiki, which only they and their teacher can
edit. Students can view the wikis of all other students in the course. " which is what I would like to do. I tried this second method, creating it as an individual wiki with a group mode of Visible Groups, However, the student is able to create content once on his first page, and then has no more ability to edit his wiki.  The edit tab isn't there at the top.  He sees a drop-down menu for the other students' wikis, and can see them, but he has no edit ability on his own wiki.  The teacher can edit all wikis. Any advice or insight one can provide would be most appreciated. Thanks Joe Amatrucola Moodle 2.6.1+ (Build: 20140131)
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: You have set the wiki  to visible group mode but are your students in the groups (in Course administration>Users>Groups) ?
Comment 2: Thanks.  No, they are not in groups.  In my scenario, what groups would I create and who would be in those groups?  I would like each student to have his own wiki, so that only the student and teacher can edit the wiki, but every student can see the wiki.  Does that mean I need to create a group for each student, and then add just one member to each group?
Comment 3: I think if you are going to use visible group mode for your wiki then yes, you would need to put your students into groups so they can edit their wikis; otherwise they can just see but not edit. (You could try on the sandbox site demo. moodle.net )
Comment 4: Understood.  I'll give it a shot.  Thanks.

Forum Post: 
Post title: ouwiki new release
Post description: (For those who are not familiar with it, the OU wiki is an alternative wiki for Moodle 1.9. It does not replace the standard wiki but is an additional option. It works with the HTML editor instead of wiki markup and is designed to be user-friendly and simple.) I have done an updated release of the OU wiki today. Read information and get it here Not many new features but it does include bugfixes, including the one Glenys posted about in this forum! If you had problems trying to install an older version, please give this one a go. For those wondering what's happening in future, there are no major changes on the horizon. We are planning to add a couple more administrative features - including the ability to revert to a previous version without having to copy/paste it - in the autumn. Also just a note - I am posting this to the wiki forum because it seemed most appropriate, but I don't actually read the wiki forum (obviously, we have our own wiki, so most of it is not relevant). I'll try to remember to keep an eye on this post for the next few days. However, if you need to report a bug, please contact me directly by email/Moodle private message. --sam
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Any chance of the search fucntion searching the comments? We've found that a huge limitation and are now testing nWiki - but nWiki only seems to work in Safari at the moment or as an admin so what we need is the OU's reliability with *some* of the extra features of the nWiki (like separated discussion/comment rather than integrated and navigation/index blocks... We can but wish!
Comment 2: Hello, IS there a way to allow students to insert images into the wiki through the menu editor? Right now it only allows a reference to an image. Thank you Leo
Comment 3: Hi Leo, This isn't an Ouwiki problem but a Moodle problem : students can only insert images which are already on the internet, so they can't upload them directly. You can get round the problem, see this video Creating assignments in Moodle for Students to Upload files. Students can also upload images in the Database module. Cheers, Glenys

Forum Post: 
Post title: Image links failing
Post description: There are various threads about problems uploading images but I can find nothing recent on how to solve problems with image links failing. I had a student inserting an image (that resided on the web) with an address that ended Laughing_buddha_statue_Buddha_gift_m.jpg The image showed up correctly in the editor but only the alternate text showed up in the preview. I tried shortening the name and then it showed up correctly. However, when I experimented to find out the length at which it failed I found I could add letters and numbers until it was way past its original length. Further experimenting suggested length was not the issue but it was to do with the use of upper-case. In particular, if the name began with an upper-case letter it could not move away from upper-case and then back again; if the letter began with lower-case there was no such restriction. So, these are OK... ABcde.jpg ABCDE.jpg abcde.jpg

Forum Post: 
Post title: Using a Wiki for Reading Summaries
Post description: I would like to teach my students how to maintain a Reading Wiki where they can keep notes on their reading. I have created the Wiki, but for each article read I would like the student to have a Summary page, a Inquiries page and a Contributors page. I am relatively unfamiliar with the terminology used in wikis so I do not know if I need to create the article name as a category and then create the Summary, Inquiries, and Contributors pages as sub-categories (pages). I had tried simply using the brackets; however, then other articles link to that page. I would appreciate any advice on how to accomplish what I am trying to do with the wikis which could be outlined as: Class Reading Wiki Article #1 Summary Inquiries Contributors Article #2 Summary Inquiries Contributors Article #3 etc, etc. The reason I want the inquiries on separate pages is that I want the students to be able to edit at the same time. In other words a student could be working on the summary page while another is simultaneously working on the inquiries. If this could be accomplished by keeping it all on one page (as it appears in Moodle Docs - which I realize is a different type of wiki) that would be fine. Thanks again for any advise as I try to incorporate this in to my class. Peace.
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: I remain hopeful that some wiki expert will be able to help me figure out how to have repetitive subpage names in a wiki. I have read the documentation in MoodleDocs to no avail. The closest thing I found was a category but I am not able to get that working. I want my students to do reading summaries and come up with questions based on the reading. I want a summary and questions subpage for each article. I understand how to create a page; however, when they create a [Questions] link on the Article 2 page it takes them to the already completed [Questions] page for Article 1. I would greatly appreciate any guidance in wrapping my mind around this wild wiki world. Peace.
Comment 2: Anthony, I am by no means an 'expert', but my solution would be to create all the required pages with individual names and then to hyperlink to the appropriate page using the menu structure that you suggest. You can even hide the original wiki that you created to create all the different pages and then create a new wiki with the hyperlinks on it, so that you dont get the legacy wiki page links. Does that make sense? It might be a bit of a fudge, but it works!
Comment 3: Nigel - Thanks for your response. I am not sure that I completely understand.  I think you are suggesting that the pages be created using names like Article1Summary, Article2Summary, etc. to prevent the linking from taking the student to the same place; however, I want it to be displayed simply as summary. My attempts at using [Article1Summary | Summary] have not worked since even after the page is created I see the wiki new page question mark. When I click on it, then it takes me to the page but it is clear to me that something is not working. I am wondering if on a page, could I have sections ? Where students could modify one section at a time. I want the student doing the summary and the student doing the questions to be able to be writing and working at the same time without interfering with one another. Unfortunately, I do not understand that a legacy wiki page link is but I would happily accept the fudge.
Comment 4: Anthony, Ludo is the wiki guru. I bet he should be able to provide guidance on this. Juvenal
Comment 5: Thank Juvenal - I am hoping that Ludo (or someone with experience using wikis in a similar way) might respond. Peace.
Comment 6: When I started to work with wikis I intended to use it for my students to write documentation for projects, and I had a similar problem. Any documenta has the same parts, and we can't have two pages named "Introduction". Mediawiki being a single wiki does not solve this issue. Moodle wikis (all of them, just by being in Moodle architecture) offer us some solutions:
Comment 7: Ludo - thanks for the reply and congrats on the recent releases. A) I am using groups which does manage setting up a wiki for each section. This aspect is working very well. B) In order to preserve the richness of wiki style interaction, I want all of the articles to be in a single wiki activity. C) I will have to check out nwiki and see if that might not be the best solution since the likelihood of having students simultaneously edit the same page can be reduced. I was trying to avoid some user frustration of being told that someone else had edited the page since them. But I do like the idea of being able to provide a style guide or template. D) Since I am working with high school students in the U.S., disciplined though they may be, it is probably best not to rely too much on a naming convention although that may be my best long term solution. Thanks for your assistance in helping me to process through the best way to implement wiki use in this situation. Peace.
Comment 8: Concurrent access management and section edit (like in wikipedia) are points of our laarge todo list. Peace !
Comment 9: I'm glad to hear that the wiki development continues. Thanks for your work at making Moodle Moodle-tastic.

Post title: Wiki login misbehaving
Post description: I am experiencing problems when users attempt to login to edit a wiki page.  The scenario is as follows: Users visit the wiki page with guest login access. Could someone enlighten me about this particular issue? Thanks Comments associated with the post: Comment 1: Dear all, I temporarily solved the issue by re-uploading all image files and attachments in the "Files" tab. Regardless of the user that originally uploaded the single files, all links inside wiki pages started working normally again. Strangely, though, the file uploader popped up an alert, asking me if I wanted to overwrite old files and images as if they were still present in the wiki. Label:

Forum Post: 
Post title: Private Wiki
Post description: Hi I know wikis are usually collaborative but is is possible to create a wiki for each individual student in a course. I want them to have a place to document their own private goals. Their goals may change as they move through the course so I want them to be able to make changes to their wiki. Some of the goals may be sensitive so I want them to feel obligated to share with the group. Is it possible to set permissions for a wiki page which relates to the student log in? Hope this makes sense. Help appreciated. Ann
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Lets say it is a graduate group of only (say) 15 students. Create groups with one student in the group and assign wiki to groups. Lets say it is an undergraduate group of 200. Are you planning to read them all?? Probably this won't work. Is a wiki overkill? Here is another option: You could use an online text assignment, CALL it a journal, which is editiable on one page an unlimited number of times. It really functions like a one editor, one page wiki.
Comment 2: Thanks - I'll go the text assignment. Cheers! Ann
Comment 3: Hi Ann The Online Text assignment would work well with this, If used it successfully in the past. You should warn your students to be careful that they don't accidentally remove existing text with each successive edit. I always recommended that students keep a backup in a Word document just in case! An alternative is the Dialogue module with allows private Teacher to Student communication however students can just keep adding entries, which are all date/time stamped. I hope this helps Cheers Teresa
Comment 4: Thanks for your help and advice! I don't seem to have Dialogue as an option in my activities list. Is this something I need to download ? Ann
Comment 5: Hi Ann Yes it is a Contributed module available on the Modules & Plugins database for download. Cheers Teresa
Comment 6: the OU wiki does exactly what you want to do. Best Fritz
Comment 7: Thanks for your response. Ann
Comment 8: Hi Ann thestandard Moodle wiki activity does exactly what you describe if you set the wiki type to 'student'. Then each student gets his/her own wiki. ralf
Comment 9: Many thanks for your response. Ann

Post title: How to export a wiki for external review
Post description: I'm using Moodle with OU Wiki, but I am hoping that an answer for the Moodle Wiki will help me. An external examiner would like me to send a sample of students' work for verification. Much of that work is in a Wiki (individual for each student). Is there a way to export a Wiki into a series of web pages (or some other way, other than clicking each link down the tree which will be very time consuming) so I can send it off for review?
Comments associated with the post: 
Comment 1: Hi John, How about trying the Wiki export plugin ? I've not had chance to try it myself, so if you try it, please let us know how you get on!
Comment 2: Hi Helen, I did recently learn about the Wiki Export plugin (and have installed it). While it does not work on the OU Wiki, it does work on the standard Wiki. However, it only exports in epub or PDF format (not HTML). It is WAY better than nothing but it is far from perfect. I'm now asking the company that maintains it to see how much it would cost to enhance the plugin.
Comment 3: Thanks John for the info, and good plan asking for the plugin to be enhanced! (I did wonder about the possibility of Portfolio export but unfortunately wikis are not one of the items which can be exported.)
Comment 4: PS Thanks John for your comment in MDL-24439 . Unfortunately the wiki activity has not had much attention in recent years. For anyone browsing this discussion, if you would like to export a wiki, please vote and/or comment on MDL-24439 .
Comment 5: Hi Helen, Thanks for this. I'm a little concerned that that issue has been up-voted 52 times but still there has been no forward movement on it since 2010.
